Yet it has proved surprisingly resilient, supported by the sturdy pillars of robust consumer spending, a rising stock market, and healthy balance sheets for households and businesses alike.

title: In the Calls of Bonobos, Scientists Hear Hints of Language
description: After listening to hundreds of hours of ape calls, a team of scientists say they have detected a hallmark of human language: the ability to put together strings of sounds to create new meanings.

title: Trump’s De Minimis Order Poised to Upend E-Commerce
description: President Trump on April 2 ordered the closure of a loophole that allows retailers to send clothes and other goods from China directly to American shoppers without paying tariffs.

title: Trump’s Tariffs: Anxiety and Assent
description: To the Editor:

title: A Chef’s Favorite Dessert Is Also the Easiest to Make
description: Eating malva pudding for the first time feels like meeting a soul mate, its swirl of butter and sugar instantly familiar to the deep heart’s core, its softness, somehow simultaneously fluffy and dense, thrilling and intimate. With each bite of the cream-soaked cake, there’s a sense of wonder: I already know you so well, have we met before?

title: Steve Rattner on Just How Bad Things Will Get Under Trump’s Tariffs
description: In this episode of “The Opinions,” the deputy Opinion editor Patrick Healy and contributing Opinion writer, investor and economic analyst Steven Rattner break down how President Trump’s “reciprocal tariffs” are already shaking the global economy — and it hasn’t even been 24 hours.

title: What to Know About Carbon Monoxide Poisoning
description: Carbon monoxide gas, which is invisible and odorless, can be fatal. It can kill people in their homes as they sleep, seeping undetected from generators. It can accumulate within the walls of closed garages, wafting from cars left running by residents seeking warmth or power in a storm.

title: She Crossed a Line That Even the Saltiest Speech Should Avoid
description: Last week Representative Jasmine Crockett of Texas landed in the hot seat for comments she made about her state’s governor, Greg Abbott. “Y’all know we got Governor Hot Wheels down there, come on now,” she said at a Human Rights Campaign event, “and the only thing hot about him is that he is a hot-ass mess, honey!”

title: F.D.A. Layoffs Could Raise Drug Costs and Erode Food Safety
description: Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. announced wide-ranging cutbacks at federal health agencies, including the Food and Drug Administration, that would eliminate duplicative services and paper pushers.

title: How Tariffs Could Upend the Transition to Cleaner Energy
description: First came President Trump’s freezing of federal support for many renewable energy projects, coupled with cries of “drill, baby, drill.”

title: What Students Are Saying About ‘College for All’
description: “The idea that every student should aim for a four-year college motivated a bipartisan movement for decades,” Dana Goldstein writes in “Why Some Schools Are Rethinking ‘College for All.’” Now, even the most enthusiastic promoters are guiding students toward a wider range of choices post-high school.

title: It’s Day 1 of a New Mayor’s Race in New York
description: No one would ever have called this year’s race for mayor of New York City a foregone conclusion — not with a former governor who resigned in disgrace, a surging democratic socialist and an incumbent battling corruption charges all in the running.

title: Canada’s Prime Minister Puts Tariffs on U.S.-Made Cars and Predicts Global Upheaval
description: Prime Minister Mark Carney said that Canada had introduced a 25 percent tariff on cars and trucks made in the United States in retaliation for the tariffs that went into effect Thursday morning on Canadian vehicles.

title: With Deadline Looming, Details of a Potential TikTok Deal Emerge
description: Two days before a deadline for TikTok to be sold to a non-Chinese company or otherwise face a ban in the United States, a deal has not yet been cemented but the contours of one are starting to take shape.

title: Hurricane Experts Forecast Another Above-Average Atlantic Hurricane Season
description: Last year was a busy hurricane season with storm after storm racing across the Caribbean, bringing multiple storms ashore in Florida, ravaging rains to the Carolina mountains and strong winds to downtown Houston; another robust season is likely to occur in the Atlantic in 2025.

title: More Grocery Stores That Are Also Great Restaurants
description: Restaurants: love ‘em, obviously. But grocery stores … those are my happy places. And when a grocery store’s got prepared food that beats anything? I’m moving in. Last year, my colleague Tanya Sichynsky did a great installment of the newsletter about grocery stores with excellent food, so consider this a sequel.

title: Murders and Shootings Tumble in New York City in First Quarter of Year
description: In the first three months of 2025, New York City recorded the fewest shootings of any first quarter since the Police Department began recording crime statistics in 1994, Commissioner Jessica Tisch announced on Thursday.

title: What to See in N.Y.C. Galleries in April
description: This week in Newly Reviewed, Martha Schwendener covers Camp’s probing videos, Mungo Thomson’s recirculating images and John Zorn’s drawings and objects.

title: Volkswagen to Add ‘Import Fee’ to Cars Sold in U.S.
description: Volkswagen, the German automaker, has told its car dealers that it plans to add an import fee later this month to the price of imported cars sold in the United States.

title: Trump’s Tariffs Could Threaten His ‘Energy Dominance’ Agenda
description: President Trump has promised to usher in an era of “energy dominance” and cut energy costs in half for consumers in his first 18 months in office. But his latest round of tariffs, announced Wednesday, have rattled energy markets and threatened to scramble global supply chains.

title: Oil Producers Follow Trump’s Tariffs With a Surprise Increase
description: Eight members of the OPEC Plus oil cartel, led by Saudi Arabia, said Thursday that they would accelerate their previously planned schedule to gradually add about 2.2 million barrels a day to the oil market.

title: ‘Lazarus’ Is a Dark and Kinetic Adventure
description: Right on the heels of “Common Side Effects” comes another animated pharmacological thriller, this time the Japanese anime series “Lazarus,” which premieres, dubbed, on Saturday at midnight, on Adult Swim. The show is set in 2055, and a miracle pain killer that claims to free people from all suffering has become ubiquitous. Years after the mysterious Dr. Skinner released this drug, Hapna, he re-emerges with a second bombshell: After three years in your system, Hapna will kill you.

title: Beatlemania: A Penetrating New Book Celebrates Lennon and McCartney
description: In our culture, music is most often written about in terms of sales, streams and chart positions. That is, of course, the least intelligent way to think about or talk about music.

title: Israeli Strike Kills Dozens at Gaza City Shelter, Officials Say
description: Dozens of people were killed on Thursday in an Israeli strike on a school-turned-shelter in Gaza City, according to local health authorities.

title: What to Know About Trump’s New Tariffs
description: President Trump announced what could be one of the most drastic economic policy changes in decades on Wednesday, when he substituted America’s longstanding system of taxing imports with a new tariff system of his own devising.

title: Fake Doctor Is Charged After ‘Butt Lift’ Surgery Leaves Woman Near Death
description: A Queens man posing as a doctor was charged with assault and practicing medicine without a license after a woman went into cardiac arrest during a botched cosmetic surgery at a makeshift home clinic, according to an internal police report.

title: E.U. Prepares Major Penalties Against Elon Musk’s X
description: European Union regulators are preparing major penalties against Elon Musk’s social media platform, X, for breaking a landmark law to combat illicit content and disinformation, said four people with knowledge of the plans, a move that is likely to ratchet up tensions with the United States by targeting one of President Trump’s closest advisers.

title: Chris Pappas Jumps Into 2026 Senate Race in New Hampshire
description: Representative Chris Pappas, a fourth-term New Hampshire Democrat, announced on Thursday that he would run for the Senate seat being vacated by the retirement of Senator Jeanne Shaheen, a fellow Democrat.

title: Leonardo Patterson, 82, High-Flying Antiquities Dealer Brought Low, Dies
description: Leonardo Patterson, who rose improbably from rural poverty in Costa Rica to the towering heights of the global antiquities market, despite accusations that he trafficked in fake and stolen artifacts — and who fell precipitously when those accusations proved to be true — died on Feb. 11 in Bautzen, a city in northeastern Germany. He was 82.

title: For Wine, Tariffs Mean Fear, Uncertainty and Higher Prices
description: The last few decades have been a glorious time for wine lovers in the United States. Consumers have had access to an unparalleled diversity of choices from around the world.

title: Friday Briefing: Trump’s Tariffs Rattle the Markets
description: Wall Street tumbled to its worst day since the pandemic yesterday in response to President Trump’s major round of tariffs on U.S. imports, as countries reeling from the blow weighed countermeasures. Stocks in Asia and Europe also fell.

title: In Worst Stock Market in Years, Slow and Boring Has Eased the Pain
description: The mood has darkened in the U.S. stock market, and no wonder. Pessimism about the Trump tariffs has set off painful declines.

title: Pentagon Will Review Hegseth’s Use of Signal
description: The Pentagon’s acting inspector general will review Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth’s disclosure on the Signal messaging app of the timing of U.S. fighter jets’ airstrikes against Iranian-backed Houthis in Yemen, the Defense Department’s watchdog agency announced Thursday.

title: Trump Just Bet the Farm
description: Donald Trump is not known for doing his homework — he’s more of a go-with-my-gut kind of guy. What I find most terrifying about what Trump is doing today is that he seems to be largely relying on his gut to bet that he can radically overturn how America’s institutions have operated and the way the nation relates to both its allies and enemies — and get it all right. As in, America will become stronger and more prosperous, while the rest of the world will just adjust. Next question.

title: Two Top Organizers of Canada’s Trucker Convoy Are Found Guilty
description: Two main architects of protests that gridlocked Canada’s capital for weeks were found guilty on Thursday in one of the last legal cases stemming from the demonstrations that convulsed the country and disrupted billions of dollars in trade with the United States.

title: Storm System Wreaks Havoc Across U.S. South and Midwest
description: Nearly 30 tornadoes were confirmed in several states after the first wave of the storm and floodwaters overtook streets in Tennessee.

title: How the Trump Administration Might Target D.E.I. in Public Schools
description: What counts as a D.E.I. program in a school? And how do such programs differ from simply learning and talking about race and identity?

title: Mel Gibson’s Gun Rights to Be Restored by Justice Dept.
description: Justice Department officials will allow the actor Mel Gibson, a prominent supporter of President Trump, to own guns again, ending a once contentious debate that had roiled the upper ranks of the department, according to people familiar with the decision.

title: One Bird Nest, 30 Years of Human Trash
description: A coot’s nest reveals that what humans throw away doesn’t really go away.

title: ‘Fair Likelihood’ Trump Administration Violated Court Order, Judge Says
description: A federal judge in Washington said on Thursday that there was a “fair likelihood” that the Trump administration had violated an order he issued last month to stop deporting Venezuelan migrants to El Salvador under an 18th-century wartime law.

title: Amid the Storm, Some of Nashville’s Tornado Sirens Run Out of Battery
description: The repeated tornado warnings across Nashville on Thursday caused some of the sirens to run out of battery and stop making noise, the Nashville Fire Department said.

title: Markets Tumbled After Trump’s Tariffs
description: President Trump had the world’s attention yesterday when he unveiled his plan to rewire the global economic order by imposing expansive tariffs on nearly all of America’s trading partners. Today, the world responded.

title: Trump Administration Moves to Cut Humanities Endowment
description: The National Endowment for the Humanities has canceled most of its grant programs and started putting staff on administrative leave, as its resources are set to be redirected toward supporting President Trump’s priorities.

title: Trump Administration Set to Pause $510 Million for Brown University
description: The Trump administration intends to block $510 million in federal contracts and grants for Brown University, expanding its campaign to hold universities accountable for what it says is relentless antisemitism on campus, according to two White House officials familiar with the plans.

title: Some Weather Service Offices Are Delaying or Skipping Storm Surveys
description: At least two offices of the National Weather Service have said they are delaying or skipping sending staff into the field to survey damage from this week’s severe weather, a key step that meteorologists usually use to confirm whether or not a tornado has struck.

title: Judge Blocks H.H.S. From Terminating $11 Billion in Public Health Grants
description: A federal judge on Thursday temporarily barred the Department of Health and Human Services from terminating a variety of public health funds that had been allocated to states during the Covid-19 pandemic, finding that the move had left those states stranded and unable to provide critical health services.

title: Tufts Student Held by ICE Asks Court to Return Her Case to Massachusetts
description: Rumeysa Ozturk, a Tufts student detained for pro-Palestinian activity, asked a federal judge in Boston on Thursday to have her case moved to Massachusetts, where she lives and was picked up by federal agents, from Louisiana, where she is being held in an immigration detention facility.

title: Trump Supports Proxy Voting for New Parents in Congress, a Blow to Johnson
description: President Trump on Thursday threw his support behind a bipartisan effort to allow proxy voting for new parents in Congress, dealing a major blow to Speaker Mike Johnson’s attempts to kill the measure.

title: John Thornton, Who Revived Local Journalism, Is Dead at 59
description: John Thornton, a financier who leveraged his wealth and influence to embark on the seemingly quixotic mission of reviving local journalism in a time of crisis, by founding The Texas Tribune, a seminal regional nonprofit news organization, and the American Journalism Project, which supports local digital newsrooms around the country, died on Saturday in Austin, Texas. He was 59.

title: Glamorous Clothes You Can Wear on the Subway
description: Growing up in Richmond, Va., Alex McEachin fell in love with clothes via movie costumes, specifically Cecil Beaton’s for “My Fair Lady” (1964) and “Gigi” (1958) and the tartan ensembles worn by Alicia Silverstone in “Clueless” (1995). For a time, she considered a career in costume design, but after working on a few school productions, she realized she was less interested in interpreting a director’s concept than in coming up with her own. To that end, she moved to New York, where, in 2017, she earned a degree from the Parsons School of Design and landed a job in product development at the fashion brand Proenza Schouler. There, for seven years, she acted as a liaison between designers and producers, shepherding ideas into finished pieces and acquiring, she says, an “almost doctoral level of education in fashion.” Now she’s applying that knowledge to her own creative vision: Accorda, an artistic yet deeply wearable fashion line that launched in February.

title: Police Officers Are Suspended After a Car Chase Ends in a Fatal Fire
description: Two New York police officers were suspended after chasing a stolen SUV that was found engulfed in flames early Wednesday morning with the driver dead inside, officials said.

title: C.E.O. Choked Man Who Danced Barefoot on Cruise Ship, U.S. Says
description: The chief executive of a major U.S. title insurance company is facing a criminal charge over choking another passenger aboard a Caribbean cruise, an altercation that an investigator said began when the C.E.O.’s wife told the other man to put on his shoes while dancing at one of the ship’s bars, the F.B.I. said on Thursday.

title: But, How Will She Teach Pilates in an Ankle Monitor?
description: A striking and headline-making fraud case resulted in a conviction last Friday, when Charlie Javice was found guilty in federal court of conning JPMorgan Chase out of $175 million. The bank has also sued Ms. Javice, a 32-year-old entrepreneur who once made the Forbes 30 Under 30 list, for elaborately falsifying her student-finance start-up’s customer list.

title: Senate Confirms Dr. Oz to Oversee Medicare and Medicaid
description: The Senate on Thursday confirmed Dr. Mehmet Oz, the celebrity TV doctor, 53-45 and along party lines to lead Medicare and Medicaid, which insure nearly half of all Americans.

title: Grocery Shoppers Will Feel the Tariffs First in the Produce Aisle
description: Grocery shoppers are likely to feel the impact of the Trump administration’s sweeping new tariffs before April is over. And the first place they’ll feel it is in parts of the store where the inventory has to move fast.

title: Workers Forced to Leave Foreign Policy Center as Trump Presses Shutdown
description: Almost all the employees of the Wilson Center, a prominent nonpartisan foreign policy think tank in Washington, were placed on leave on Thursday and blocked from their work email accounts as Elon Musk’s task force quickly shut down most of the center.

title: Tornadoes Sweep Across the South and Midwest, Killing at Least 7
description: At least seven people have been killed in Tennessee, Missouri and Indiana, officials said on Thursday, after more than 30 tornadoes, combined with hail and heavy rains, swept through the South and Midwest, flooding streets, snapping power lines and flattening homes and businesses.

title: Police Shut Area Near Seoul Court as Protesters Amass Before Ruling
description: The authorities in South Korea were expecting tens of thousands of protesters to descend on central Seoul on Friday as the nation’s Constitutional Court decides the fate of President Yoon Suk Yeol.

title: L.A. Fires Death Toll Rises to 30 After Remains Are Found
description: Nearly three months after the January wildfires in Los Angeles, investigators discovered human remains in a burned lot on Wednesday in Altadena, Calif., raising the total death toll from the fires to 30.

title: Amtrak Train Strikes and Kills 3 People in Pennsylvania
description: Amtrak suspended service for several hours between Penn Station in New York and the main rail station in Philadelphia after one of its trains struck and killed a father and two of his adult sons in Bristol, Pa., on Thursday.

title: Lawsuit Challenges Trump’s Legal Rationale for Tariffs on China
description: The New Civil Liberties Alliance — a nonprofit group that describes itself as battling “violations by the administrative state” — sued the federal government on Thursday over the means by which it  imposed steep new levies on Chinese imports earlier this year.

title: Corrections: April 4, 2025
description: An article on Monday about a veteran who worked for the U.S. government for over two decades and was among the employees whose job was cut at the Department of Veterans Affairs by the Trump administration misstated which employees were included in staffing cuts of probationary employees at the department. No psychiatrists were included among those cuts.

title: Scenes From States Devastated by a Powerful Storm System
description: A huge storm system has pummeled the Midwest and South this week, killing at least 14 people and leaving a trail of destruction from Texas to Ohio. The risk may only increase in the days ahead as sustained rainfall is expected to cause widespread and potentially catastrophic floods.

title: Most Likely to Pay Out
description: Jump to: Tricky Clues

title: Trump Administration Sends Harvard a List of Demands to Protect Federal Funds
description: The Trump administration sent Harvard a list of demands on Thursday that would have to be met to end a government review of $9 billion the school receives in federal funding.

title: Friday Briefing: Trump’s Tariffs Rattle the Markets
description: Wall Street tumbled to its worst day since the pandemic yesterday in response to President Trump’s major round of tariffs on U.S. imports, as countries reeling from the blow weighed countermeasures. Stocks in Asia and Europe also fell.

title: Head of National Security Agency and Cyber Command Is Ousted
description: The head of the National Security Agency and U.S. Cyber Command was removed from his job on Thursday, according to the top Democrats on the congressional intelligence committees.

title: Quote of the Day: Trade War Has Stocks Tumbling Everywhere
description: “Investors no longer see tariffs as a one-time event risk, but an always-present risk.”

title: Review: Clooney, Fair and Balanced, in ‘Good Night, and Good Luck’
description: “This just might do nobody any good” is a chancy first line for a play.

title: After a Night Out in Hanoi, Reconnecting Five Years Later
description: It was in a hotel lobby bar in Hanoi, Vietnam, that Samuel Toff Karp and Kara Julia Rosenberg met in the summer of 2016. They were on separate trips with friends across Southeast Asia, and Ms. Rosenberg’s group invited Mr. Karp to come along with them to an underground club.

title: Why I Lied About Being Married
description: When we called my parents to tell them we were engaged, my father said to my mother, “Is she pregnant?”

title: A First Kiss in an Elevator Was ‘More Than Fireworks’
description: Virginia McIntosh Venuto and Shauna Hakim Miller had both recently ended long-term relationships when they met on Tinder in September 2022. Mx. Venuto, who calls herself Gin, was new to online dating, while Ms. Miller described herself as a “seasoned pro.”

title: She Tuned Into His ‘Commanding’ Voice at Columbia
description: Chambers Boyd Moore instantly recognized Thomas Philip Moore’s distinctive voice as it rose up from a group standing behind her at a cocktail party kicking off their 30th Columbia Journalism School reunion weekend in April 2022.

title: An Epic Celebration in Guatemala, Ruins and Volcano Included
description: On March 21, Keri Ann Meslar and Trevor Thomas Galko stood in the back of the Convento Santa Clara, the sprawling ruins of the Santa Clara Church in Antigua, Guatemala, arm in arm, watching their friends and family singing and dancing during a surprise firework show to close out their wedding celebration. In the distance the Volcán de Agua, a towering 12,000-foot volcano, loomed. The song “Wake Me Up” by Avicii blasted through the 18th-century convent and gardens.

title: As Unexplained Quakes Ease, Santorini Insists It’s Open for Business
description: Weeks after being rattled by thousands of mostly small-scale earthquakes, the island of Santorini, the jewel in the crown of Greece’s tourism sector, is determined to return to business as usual — even as the quake phenomenon remains a mystery.

title: They Fought to Save Lives in Myanmar. The Earthquake Claimed Theirs.
description: The five young doctors took up their mission together: defying Myanmar’s junta to treat the wounded through the coup and deadly military crackdown four years ago. Since then, each continued supporting the democratic cause.

title: U.S. Strikes in Yemen Burning Through Munitions With Limited Success
description: President Trump said this week that Iranian-backed Houthi militants in Yemen have been “decimated by the relentless strikes” that he ordered beginning on March 15.

title: What to Know About the Removal of South Korea’s President
description: South Korea’s Constitutional Court on Friday upheld the impeachment of President Yoon Suk Yeol, removing him from office four months after his short-lived imposition of martial law on Dec. 3.

title: Seoul Erupts With Emotion After Yoon Is Removed From Office
description: For hours, the atmosphere in the streets surrounding South Korea’s Constitutional Court in downtown Seoul had been tense. Dozens had camped out overnight in the early spring chill in the lead-up to the court’s historical decision on Friday.

title: This Is Not the Right Way to Curb Migration
description: The Trump administration last month deported scores of Venezuelan men to El Salvador, sending them to a maximum-security prison for gang members. The administration claimed that most of the men were members of the Venezuelan gang Tren de Aragua, a group that, according to the executive order decreeing the deportations, is “conducting irregular warfare and undertaking hostile actions against the United States.”

title: Trump Officials Have Not Funded Radio Free Europe, Despite Court Order
description: The Trump administration has failed to disburse congressionally approved funding for Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, the news network originally set up to counter Soviet propaganda during the Cold War, despite a judge’s order to keep it operating, according to court filings and officials at the news organization.

title: Stocks Drop Again as Trade War Intensifies
description: The global rout in stock markets continued on Friday as worries deepened about a trade war, after China retaliated against President Trump’s sweeping tariffs with steep levies of its own on U.S. goods.

title: Stephen Colbert Likens Trump’s Tariffs to an Economic Infection
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

title: Word of the Day: salinity
description: The word salinity has appeared in 26 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on March 25 in “Salty Suburban Roads Are Clouding the Future of N.Y.C. Drinking Water” by Hilary Howard:

title: Faced With a Changed Ally, Australia Debates the Need for a ‘Plan B’
description: Australia is one of America’s closest allies; the two countries have fought alongside each other in every major conflict since World War I. Jake Sullivan, former President Joe Biden’s national security adviser, said in January that the two had effectively entered a “strategic marriage.”

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.

title: Key Evidence Thrown Out in Jolt to ‘Orgasmic Meditation’ Conspiracy Case
description: Two women accused in Brooklyn of mistreating employees of their “orgasmic meditation” group argued that key evidence against them had been concocted for a true-crime documentary and had it thrown out of court.

title: The Ex-Convict Who Turned Down Columbia’s Ph.D. Offer
description: Late in February, Ibrahim Rivera opened his email to receive the happy news that at 54, he had been accepted to the doctoral program in social work at Columbia University. The letter notifying him of his admission made a point of his “outstanding academic record, professional achievements and excellent potential for independent scholarship with high impact.” He was offered, in addition to full compensation for tuition, roughly $44,000 a year in stipends on top of whatever fellowships he might receive.

title: What Eric Adams’s Choice to Skip the Democratic Primary Means for Voters
description: Mayor Eric Adams said on Thursday that he will skip the Democratic primary and run for re-election as an independent candidate, adding another unusual twist to an unpredictable mayoral campaign. His decision came one day after a judge dismissed the five-count federal corruption indictment against him, following pressure from the Justice Department under President Trump.

title: Yoon Ejected as South Korean Court Upholds Impeachment
description: South Korea’s Constitutional Court ruled unanimously to remove former President Yoon Suk Yeol. Protesters reacted to the decision, some cheered while others showed their disappointment.

title: Hold On!
description: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this photo, or describe a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.

title: Do You Have a Vibrant and Healthy Social Life?
description: How long has it been since you’ve had a meaningful face-to-face interaction with a friend?

title: Who Is Yoon Suk Yeol, and What Comes Next for Him?
description: Yoon Suk Yeol’s political career may be over, but his troubles are not.

title: ‘A Minecraft Movie’ | Anatomy of a Scene
description: Jared Hess narrates a mine cart sequence from his film, featuring Jack Black, Jason Momoa and Sebastian Hansen.

title: When Kenyan Maids Sought Help Overseas, Diplomats Demanded Sex
description: Selestine Kemoli fled to the Kenyan Embassy in Riyadh in 2020, terrified and desperate.

title: 30 Years Ago, This Book Saw the Coming Backlash Against Elites
description: If you want to understand what Christopher Lasch was trying to say in his 1995 book “The Revolt of the Elites” — and why what he said then matters now — take a walk through the Hudson Yards development on the West Side of Manhattan. When I worked there, the area was dominated by rail yards and warehouses. A decade later, the neighborhood is a soaring ode to luxury. There’s a hotel by the high-end gym chain Equinox. One skyscraper’s ground floor is dominated by an “unprecedented space” (per website copy) from the celebrity chef José Andrés. It’s supposed to be a bustling market in the style of Barcelona’s legendary Boqueria, but its sterile opulence is closer in sensibility to the nearby Fendi boutique, only with ham.

title: Russia Executes P.O.W.s Without Caring Who Watches, Ukraine Says
description: On a Monday morning last fall, Ukrainian drone pilots watched what had become a familiar scene unfold on a drone’s live feed: Russian soldiers pointed their guns at two Ukrainians, who seemingly surrendered. Then, the footage showed, the Russians shot them point blank.

title: Trump’s Next Tariffs Target Could Be Foreign-Made Medicines
description: The drug industry got a temporary reprieve on Wednesday when foreign-made medicines were exempted from President Trump’s far-reaching new tariffs.

title: A Film Tries to Make Sense of Andy Kaufman’s Comedy of Discomfort
description: A documentary subject like the comic Andy Kaufman, who died in 1984, has got to be both a dream and a nightmare for a filmmaker. Archival footage is usually used to suggest a glimpse into who someone “really” was, but Kaufman’s public appearances almost always involved him playing some kind of character, like the sweetly hapless Foreign Man (who evolved into Latka Gravas on “Taxi”) or the abrasively awful nightclub singer Tony Clifton. Kaufman suggested — and friends concur in “Thank You Very Much” (available to rent or buy on most major platforms) — that he was always playing a character, even if that character was a guy named Andy Kaufman. Trying to get at the “real” guy in this case seems quixotic.

title: Childhood Memories of Connecting Through Cartooning
description: Through much of my childhood growing up in Rockland County, N.Y., I spent far more time with comic strips and comic books than with other children. The emotional landscape of Charles M. Schulz’s “Peanuts” reflected my own insecurities and loneliness. Later, when I started reading comic books, I was especially drawn to the Fantastic Four, a superhero family whose combustible dynamics felt all too familiar.

title: Ruth Asawa’s Astonishing Universe Began at Her Door
description: If you passed through the unlocked gate and rambling garden into Ruth Asawa’s Noe Valley home between 1966 and 2000, the 5-foot-tall Japanese American artist would likely have persuaded you to lie down on the kitchen table or living room floor and let her cover your face in plaster. Ethereal clusters of her undulating, looped-wire sculptures would have dangled from the rafters of the cathedral ceiling while her six children, and later 10 grandchildren, ran underfoot.

title: A Subversive Family Memoir Tinged With Tragedy and Mustard Gas
description: Joe Dunthorne’s new memoir, “Children of Radium,” is an investigation into the life of his great-grandfather, Siegfried, who was involved in developing chemical weapons for the Nazis — which makes the book sound broadly unfun.

title: When Left Is Too Left in a Canada Rattled by Trump
description: The pain of having teeth pulled and gums prodded for denture fittings was followed by relief at the payment counter: The $4,000 worth of work would cost Ron Brydges nothing under Canada’s new national dental care program.

title: $1.8 Million Homes in Quebec
description: Set near the shore of this southern Quebec town’s eponymous lake, this four-bedroom, three-bathroom house is part of a community of 32 custom homes built in 2021. The property was a weekend home for the sellers, who are returning full-time to Montreal.

title: Invasion of the Home Humanoid Robots
description: On a recent morning, I knocked on the front door of a handsome two-story home in Redwood City, Calif. Within seconds, the door was opened by a faceless robot dressed in a beige bodysuit that clung tight to its trim waist and long legs.

title: You Have the Right to an Attorney. In Texas, That Right Is Routinely Denied.
description: San Jacinto County prosecuted nearly 300 misdemeanor cases in 2023. In this poor region, nestled in the piney woods of East Texas, many defendants were likely eligible for a government-paid lawyer. Yet the county reported it had provided an attorney to just nine people.

title: 5 Children’s Movies to Stream Now
description: Based on Judith Viorst’s beloved children’s book “Alexander and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Day,” this new iteration of the tale centers on Alexander Garcia (the adorable Thom Nemer from FX’s “Snowfall”) and a road trip gone, of course, horribly wrong. Alex’s mother, Val (Eva Longoria), wants to inspire some family bonding by bringing her children to Mexico City to get in touch with their roots. So — along with his father, Frank (Jesse Garcia), and older sister, Mia (Paulina Chávez) — Alex gets ready to set off in a fancy recreational vehicle.

title: Hiding ‘Girl With a Pearl Earring’ From the Nazis
description: At first it went to a bomb shelter in the basement of a museum, then an art bunker built into the dunes on the North Sea in the Netherlands. Toward the end of the war it was hidden in a secured cave in Maastricht, a Dutch city near the Belgian border.

title: She Was Tired and Unsteady on Her Feet. Was It Just Age?
description: “Your blood count is dangerously low,” the doctor said over the phone. “I’m sending an ambulance to take you to the hospital because you certainly cannot drive.” Her voice was calm but determined. The woman on the other end of the line was quiet for a moment, then said: “OK, I’ll go, but I don’t need an ambulance. I have a friend who can take me.”

title: Trump Sidelines Justice Dept. Legal Office, Eroding Another Check on His Power
description: The Justice Department’s Office of Legal Counsel has traditionally been a powerful guardrail in American government.

title: U.S. Employers Added 228,000 Jobs in March, but Outlook Is Clouded
description: U.S. employers accelerated hiring in March, a surprising show of strength that analysts warned might be the high-water mark for the labor market as the Trump administration’s economic policies began to play out.

title: Will Adams Voters Stick With Him in November?
description: Good morning. It’s Friday. Today we’ll look at Mayor Eric Adams’s decision to run for re-election as an independent. We’ll also look at why swastikas carved on Teslas present a quandary for law enforcement officials.

title: Why Are So Many Young Adults Getting Cancer?
description: When I started working in the intensive care unit of a cancer hospital, I didn’t know what to make of the horror stories of patients in their 30s and 40s. There was a young father with colon cancer. A recent college graduate with an aggressive malignancy that had destroyed her jaw and airway. An aspiring journalist with breast cancer that had spread to her lungs.

title: How to Protect Your Retirement Savings Now as Markets Plunge
description: “Stay the course.” “Tune out the noise.” “Focus on the long term.”

title: The Failed Ideas That Drive Elon Musk
description: President Trump has reportedly told cabinet members that Elon Musk may soon leave the administration. If and when he goes, what will he leave behind?

title: 10 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
description: Jack Black and Jason Momoa star as gamers who find a portal into a virtual world made of blocks in this wacky video-game adaptation directed by Jared Hess.

title: Is Claudia Sheinbaum the Anti-Trump?
description: Last year was a bad one for incumbent political parties, as voters worldwide rebelled against representatives of the status quo. It was a bad year for the left, with Donald Trump winning in the United States and reactionary nativism advancing across Europe. And it was a bad year for women in politics; as the BBC reported, in 60 percent of the countries that had elections in 2024, the number of women in legislatures fell.

title: A Designer Who Thrived in the Serenity of Lapland
description: In the early 1960s, Lisa Ponti, an Italian artist and journalist, who was the daughter of the designer Gio Ponti, paid a visit to the vacation home of her friends Tapio Wirkkala and Rut Bryk. This was no small journey. Her hosts, married designers based in Helsinki, summered with their children, Sami and Maaria, in the northernmost part of Finnish Lapland.

title: Ancient Hunting Kit Is Found in West Texas
description: The 6,500-year-old hunting kit contained pieces of a spear thrower and a boomerang, as well as wood- and stone-tipped darts. It was found in a cave in West Texas near the remains of a small fire, and a pile of well-preserved human waste — evidence of those who had once sheltered inside.

title: How Trump Has Tuned Out a Key Justice Dept. Legal Office
description: The Trump administration has taken steps and made claims that clash with legal opinions issued by a traditionally powerful agency that is part of the Justice Department, the Office of Legal Counsel.

title: Trump’s Threatened Tariff on Buyers of Venezuelan Oil Could Squeeze China
description: President Trump’s threatened tariffs on countries that buy oil from Venezuela are another example of how his trade moves could hit China the hardest even when China is not named as the target.

title: Trump Blocked America’s Front Door to China. Now He’s Closing Back Doors.
description: With the tariffs that President Trump unveiled on Wednesday, he is not just closing America’s front door to Chinese exports — he is slamming the back doors shut as well.

title: Cockles, Mussels and Bodyguards: Dublin Acts to Protect Molly Malone Statue
description: In song, and then in bronze, she has become an emblem of Irish culture and an enduring symbol of working-class Dublin.

title: I Led Harvard’s Medical School, and I Fear for What’s to Come
description: The recent announcement that the Trump administration will review $9 billion in federal grants and contracts awarded to Harvard, citing the university’s inadequate response to antisemitism, marks a dramatic moment in Harvard’s history. I’ve been a member of the Harvard Medical School faculty for 47 years, and I view this federal intrusion as an existential threat to the university I hold dear. I say this as a vocal critic of recent university culture and policy, including its handling of antisemitism. How did we get here?

title: How Jack Black and Jason Momoa Share a Mine Cart in ‘A Minecraft Movie’
description: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

title: A 270-Year-Old Scottish Folk Fiddle Makes Its Carnegie Hall Debut
description: Of course there will be bagpipes on Saturday, the eve of Tartan Day, when Carnegie Hall will host a lineup of stars. Among the luminaries of Scottish traditional music will be Julie Fowlis, who was featured in the soundtrack to Disney’s “Brave”; and Dougie MacLean, the singer-songwriter whose “Caledonia” has became an anthem for Scottish sports fans.

title: Where Will We Eat When the Middle-Class Restaurant Is Gone?
description: When Daniel Cox was growing up in Rochester, N.Y., he spent every Saturday night at Pizza Hut with his father and two brothers. The server got to know the family so well that when she saw their blue Dodge Caravan roll up, she would put their order in: two cheese pan pizzas and two pitchers of Pepsi.

title: F.B.I. Leaders Push to Restore Trust in the Agency They Once Undermined
description: Before they took control of the F.B.I., the bureau’s two top leaders, Kash Patel and Dan Bongino, were some of the agency’s most rabid critics, attacking it at every turn for years.

title: ‘Dying for Sex’ Review: She’s Not Looking for Love
description: Oh how the body keeps the score in “Dying for Sex,” an eight-episode FX dramedy, arriving Friday on Hulu, about a woman with terminal cancer. And if the big mort is near, maybe some petite mort is in order.

title: Inside One Migrant’s Accidental Journey to a Salvadoran Prison
description: The harrowing story of Kilmar Armando Abrego Garcia began six years ago on a March morning, when he dropped his pregnant girlfriend off at her job in suburban Maryland and made his way to a local Home Depot, hoping to find work as a casual day laborer.

title: To Trump, U.S. Economy Is a ‘Sick Patient’ and Tariffs Are the Cure
description: In the weeks leading up to his expansive global tariffs, President Trump and his top aides tried to prime the public for economic pain. They warned that while there would be fallout from their aggressive trade strategy, it would prove short-lived and benefit the economy in the long run.

title: Is Hawaiian Pizza a ‘Classic’?
description: Judge John Hodgman rules on Canada's most infamous culinary export.

title: The Very Territorial Caterpillar
description: When territorial animals are confronted by intruders, they instinctively protect their turf — no matter how small.

title: Meet Jensen McRae and 3 Other Artists on the Rise
description: They come from different coasts and countries, with sounds ranging from folk pop to hard-nosed rap to otherworldly electronics. And this year, they’re all releasing new music, going on tour or both.

title: Your Life Will Never Be the Same After These Tariffs
description: These tariffs are going to hurt. A lot. By my calculations, this round of tariffs may be 50 times as painful as the ones Donald Trump instituted in his first term. That means they are going to reshape your life in much more fundamental ways.

title: The New York Times News Quiz, April 4, 2025
description: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

title: This Habit Is Quietly Ruining Your Relationships
description: One night last week, my husband, Tom, and I got into an argument. The next morning, I was still fuming. So I gave him the silent treatment.

title: ‘What Is Our Country Becoming?’ Four Columnists Map Out Where Trump Is Taking America.
description: ​Patrick Healy, the deputy Opinion editor, hosted an online conversation with four Times Opinion columnists about how President Trump is changing America.

title: Welcome to Birmingham, England — Mind the Rats
description: A pungent smell of rotting garbage fills the air. Bulging sacks of trash pile high, some spilling their festering contents. And, with vermin plaguing parts of the city, at least one resident has claimed to have been bitten by a rat.

title: Risking Reprisals, Protesters in Gaza Call on Hamas to Step Aside
description: In a rare and perilous public show of anger against Hamas, hundreds of Palestinians marched through Beit Lahia in northern Gaza this week, demanding that the militant group relinquish control of the territory and end the war with Israel, according to four witnesses.

title: Connections Companion No. 664
description: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

title: Wordle Review No. 1,386
description: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

title: Fear and Fury: The Fallout From Trump’s Tariffs
description: The reverberations from President Trump’s new global tariffs have rocked financial markets and world capitals. American stocks have plunged, and foreign leaders have issued forceful condemnations.

title: The Worst Stock Market Drop in Years, and Dr. Oz’s New Government Job
description: On Today’s Episode:

title: Trump’s Trade War Escalates as China Retaliates With 34% Tariffs
description: China has struck back at President Trump.

title: India Passes Contentious Bill Increasing Oversight of Muslim Land Trusts
description: The Indian Parliament passed a controversial bill on Friday that increases government oversight of properties held by Muslim trusts, despite vocal protests that the religious minority was being singled out for interference.

title: ‘Wait, Baby, Wait’: Slumping Oil Prices Reflect Economic Worries
description: Many oil and gas executives thought they had hit pay dirt with President Trump’s election. A Trump administration would be staffed by people sympathetic to the industry. More areas would be opened to drilling and costly regulations swept away.

title: Europe’s Paradox
description: As the United States deserts Ukraine, and Europe with it, leaders on the continent are closing ranks and arming up to defend their democracies against Russia. In Britain, Prime Minister Keir Starmer elicits comparisons to Winston Churchill. In France, President Emmanuel Macron is channeling Charles de Gaulle’s argument for independence from Washington. Germany changed its strict budget rules to spend more on defense. Marco Rubio, the U.S. secretary of state, came to Brussels yesterday to urge them on.

title: Tech Stock Shock + Solving the Mystery of OpenAI’s ‘Blip’ + Tinder’s Flirt-Off
description: This week, President Trump announced sweeping new tariffs that are roiling the global economy. We discuss what this could mean for the tech sector and whether this will give China a competitive advantage over the United States in the development of A.I. Then, we chat with a Wall Street Journal reporter, Keach Hagey, about her new book on Sam Altman and how she solved the mystery of his firing from OpenAI. And finally, Tinder has a new chatbot that you can practice your flirting skills with — which means it’s time for a flirting competition.

title: South Korea Removes Its Impeached President and Regains Direction
description: South Korea’s top court ended months of political turmoil when it unanimously decided to remove the impeached president Yoon Suk Yeol on Friday, clearing the way for the country to elect a new leader.

title: Will Trump’s Tariffs Drive Europe Into China’s Arms, or Into a Fight?
description: President Trump’s tariffs mean that companies across the European Union and around the world are at risk of losing access to the world’s largest consumer market.

title: Israeli Military Expands Ground Operations in Gaza City
description: The Israeli military pressed deeper into northern Gaza by ground on Friday after issuing a series of evacuation orders calling on Palestinians to flee, part of its escalating offensive against Hamas in the war-battered Gaza Strip.

title: Tariffs Drive Another Market Meltdown
description: Investors are bracing for another nerve-racking ride after Thursday’s sell-off vaporized $2.5 trillion from the S&P 500 on fears of trade wars, a resurgence in inflation and a chill in global growth.

title: Boy Swept Away by Raging Waters in Kentucky as Rain Soaks Central U.S.
description: Over the past few days, more than 30 tornadoes have shredded a vast stretch of the central United States, and relentless rain has pushed creeks and streams beyond their banks. In Kentucky, floodwaters swept away a 9-year-old boy, making him at least the eighth person killed by the violent series of storms.

title: Still Receive Paper Checks From the Government? That Will Soon End.
description: Paper checks issued for tax refunds, Social Security payments and other government benefits have been dwindling and will soon be eliminated, potentially affecting hundreds of thousands of Americans.

title: At ‘Good Night’ Opening, the Stars Came Out for Clooney
description: In the wake of President Trump unleashing a new series of tariffs that sent markets into a steep decline, a group of stars shoved into the Winter Garden Theater in Midtown Manhattan to see a play that lionizes the press, takes aim at right-wing politicians, and features actors talking about how they wake up in the morning unable to recognize the world around them.

title: In Burisma Letter, Hunter Biden Sought Support from State Department
description: The State Department last week released a letter that Hunter Biden wrote while his father was serving as vice president in which he sought assistance from the U.S. government for the Ukrainian energy company Burisma.

title: Russell Brand Is Charged With Rape and Sexual Assault in U.K.
description: Prosecutors in Britain have charged Russell Brand, the comedian and actor, with multiple counts of sexual assault, including two counts of rape.

title: ‘Yellowjackets’ Season 3, Episode 9 Recap: Motive
description: The penultimate episode of Season 3 opens with a reference to “The Goonies,” the 1985 Richard Donner kids’ adventure movie beloved by Gen X.

title: Skeletons of the Roman Empire Are Found Under a Vienna Soccer Field
description: Under a soccer field in a Vienna neighborhood along the Danube, archaeologists have found a mass grave dating to the era when the Roman Empire was battling Germanic tribes almost 2,000 years ago, experts announced this week.

title: Chinese Woman Detained in Arizona Border Station Dies by Suicide
description: A Chinese woman detained by U.S. border officers for overstaying a visitor visa died by suicide while being held at a border patrol station in Arizona, a Democratic congresswoman said.

title: Federal Worker Unions Sue to Block Trump From Stripping Bargaining Rights
description: A group of federal employee unions filed a lawsuit seeking to stop the Trump administration’s efforts to strip union representation from about one million federal workers, arguing that President Trump had exceeded his constitutional authority and violated the unions’ rights.

title: Meet the 23-Year-Old Student Who Raised $25 Million in Democratic Losses
description: After the Democratic candidates in Florida’s special elections burned through millions and millions of dollars on the way to double-digit losses this week, some Democrats are asking where that money deluge came from — and where it all went.

title: Trump Sounds Defiant Note as Tariffs Roil Markets Again
description: Two days after President Trump announced his expansive global tariffs, the United States confronted wide-ranging and painful blowback, as China retaliated against American goods and markets plummeted again on worries of a persistent, damaging trade war.

title: Trump Weighs In, Making Marine Le Pen’s Case Part of the Politics of Grievance
description: “FREE MARINE LE PEN!”

title: Sam Keen, Philosopher of the Men’s Movement, Is Dead at 93
description: Sam Keen, a pop psychologist and philosopher whose best-selling book “Fire in the Belly: On Being a Man” urged men to get in touch with their primal masculinity and became a touchstone of the so-called men’s movement of the 1990s, died on March 19 in Oahu, Hawaii. He was 93.

title: Broiled Fish Tacos, Buttermilk Pancakes, Chicken Adobo
description: Good morning. I woke up chuckling.

title: Five International Movies to Stream Now
description: The Taiwanese director John Hsu’s rollicking horror-comedy raked in awards, raves and strong box-office numbers last year for very good reason. Set in a world where ghosts compete to get haunting licenses, which allow them to stay on among the living and avoid permanently fading away, “Dead Talents Society” marries the gonzo style of “Beetlejuice” with the interpersonal antics and conflicts of the best backstage dramas. The world of the film is built out with exquisite, tongue-in-cheek detail: Specters hustle to get on the covers of magazines called “Death” and “Morgue,” win endorsement deals for formaldehyde brands, and adapt tried-and-true tricks — emerging from closets, crawling backward — to the new age of internet scares.

title: Renewed Israeli Strikes Deepen Gaza’s Displacement Crisis
description: The United Nations estimates that 280,000 Gazans have been displaced since the collapse of the temporary truce between Hamas and Israel on March 18. The New York Times examined one strike that destroyed an evacuated displacement camp, killing the 4-year-old Razan Hamdiye.

title: 13 Off Broadway Shows to Tempt You in April
description: Theater in New York is nearing its seasonal crescendo, with stages Off Broadway and beyond teeming with activity. Of the many notable productions happening in April, here is a baker’s dozen to tantalize you.

title: Powell Says Trump’s Tariffs Raise Risks of Faster Inflation and Slower Growth
description: Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, warned that President Trump’s tariffs risk stoking even higher inflation and slower growth than initially expected, as he struck a more downbeat tone about the outlook, despite the economy so far remaining in a “good place.”

title: Wasn’t Trump Supposed to Have Solved the War in Ukraine by Now?
description: Given the head-spinning pace of President Trump’s proclamations and executive orders, it is not surprising that yesterday’s shock is continually being buried under today’s awe. Take Ukraine, for example. Even before coming back to the White House, Trump said he wanted a quick end to the war, starting with a 30-day cease-fire.

title: The Life and Death of a Block Destroyed By the L.A. Fires
description: A block is more than just houses — it’s one of our most basic forms of community. This is the story of what’s lost when a whole block burns.

title: Columbia Displays More Aggressive Posture in Dealing With Demonstrators
description: Columbia University students have long had a basic understanding about their relationship with the school’s Public Safety Department. Unlike at most American universities, which employ a full-fledged police force, Columbia’s public safety officers rarely, if ever, touch students.

title: The Strange Allure of Watching Other People Tear Up Their Homes
description: You see her first from behind, just before she steps away toward a tall, plain wall. You get time for a blink — that’s it, maybe a tenth of a second — and then a sonic boom of indie pop drills into you, drums and rattling high-hats and a detonation of ahhhs, as a jump cut reveals that the double-height wall has been newly repainted and festooned with quadrilateral molding, angles prim enough to have been sliced by a chef’s knife.

title: Something Else for Europe and the U.S. to Disagree About: ‘Free Speech’
description: President Trump and Europe are clashing over tariffs, the war in Ukraine and the very purpose of the European Union’s existence. But they are also divided over free speech — with potentially far-reaching implications for how the digital world is regulated.

title: Tempted to Panic-Buy? Sit Down and Have a $1.50 Hot Dog Instead.
description: I went to Costco on a tariff run, and did not stock up on anything.

title: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Netflix in April
description: Every month, Netflix adds movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for some of April’s most promising new titles for U.S. subscribers. (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)

title: Residents Sift Debris as Storm Sweeps the South and Midwest
description: The storm has generated more than 30 tornadoes this week, killing at least eight people in three states.

title: Nintendo Delays Preorders for the Switch 2, Citing Tariffs
description: The Japanese video game company Nintendo said on Friday that it would delay preorders for its new console, the Switch 2, in the United States because of the tariffs imposed by President Trump.

title: U.S. Patience on Ukraine Is Running Out, Rubio Warns Russia
description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio said on Friday that Russia is running out of time to convince the Trump administration that it is serious about striking a peace deal with Ukraine and not just playing for time.

title: Song of the Week: Is ‘Nokia’ Drake’s Comeback?
description: Is this the start of a Drake comeback? Join our critic Jon Caramanica in his car as he listens to — and breaks down — one of the most interesting tracks of the moment.

title: Newsom Will Seek Trade Deals That Spare California From Retaliatory Tariffs
description: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California is trying to get around President Trump’s tariffs to protect trade in a state with the world’s fifth-largest economy, asking his administration on Friday to pursue new international trade deals to exempt California products from any retaliatory tariffs.

title: Sean Combs Faces New Sex-Trafficking Charge Ahead of Trial
description: Federal prosecutors have amended the indictment against Sean Combs, who is scheduled to stand trial next month, to include a second major sex-trafficking charge, according to a grand jury indictment unsealed on Friday.

title: On Fox News, All Is Calm
description: At 11 a.m. on Friday, the S&P 500 was down about 4 percent, on top of a nearly 5 percent drop the day before.

title: Why Trump’s Tariffs Are Rattling Even Meta
description: When President Trump announced sweeping tariffs this week, some of the biggest tech companies had obvious reasons for worry.

title: Triage
description: The cease-fire between Israel and Hamas collapsed last month, and the dead and wounded again pour into the hospital. The injured are triaged at a tent in the hospital’s courtyard, set up to relieve the pressure on the packed emergency room inside.

title: For Pierce Brosnan, the World Is Just Enough
description: On the last day of March, at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum in Manhattan, fans approached the actor Pierce Brosnan every few minutes. Some addressed him as Mr. Brosnan, some as Mr. Bond, a reference to the four James Bond movies he made in the 1990s and early 2000s. (Brosnan has a face that demands honorifics.)

title: Felon Freed by Trump Is Sent Back to Prison After Child Assault Charge
description: A violent felon whose sentence was commuted by President Trump was arrested Friday and charged with violating the terms of his supervised release after he was accused of a string of crimes that included assaulting a 3-year-old child.

title: Trump Calls India a Friend, but Is Trying to Block Its Imports
description: Sizing up what President Trump’s new tariffs mean for India was a puzzle from the start for even the country’s top trade economists. Its politicians, too, were stunned.

title: Differing Portraits of American Campuses
description: To the Editor:

title: SpaceX Astronauts Splash Down Off California Coast for the First Time
description: Four private astronauts ended a mission in a SpaceX vehicle on Friday by splashing down in waters near Oceanside, Calif.

title: Miley Cyrus’s Apocalyptic Pop, and 9 More New Songs
description: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes) and at Apple Music here, and sign up for The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.

title: Trump Extends Deadline for a TikTok Deal
description: President Trump on Friday granted TikTok another reprieve by announcing that he would extend the deadline for when the popular app had to make a deal to be separated from its Chinese owner, ByteDance, or face a ban in the United States.

title: This Flour Makes Gluten-Free Baking So Good
description: The immediate reaction to finding out you can no longer have gluten may be despair — especially if you love to bake. But gluten-free flours are increasingly easy to find in markets, offering a gustatory lifeline for those with gluten intolerance or celiac disease.

title: Russian Strike Kills 18, Including 9 Children, Ukraine Says
description: A Russian missile strike Friday on Kryvyi Rih, a city in central Ukraine, killed at least 18 people, including nine children, and wounded more than 60, local officials said. It was the latest in a series of Russian attacks on urban centers in recent days, despite ongoing cease-fire talks, that have caused significant civilian casualties.

title: Appeals Court Orders Thousands of Voters to Verify Information in Contested N.C. Election
description: In the prolonged legal battle over a North Carolina Supreme Court seat, a state appeals court panel ruled on Friday that tens of thousands of voters must promptly verify their eligibility or have their ballots thrown out. The decision could lead to the results of the November election being overturned.

title: Robert S. Rifkind, Who Defended a Libel Suit by Ariel Sharon, Dies at 88
description: Robert S. Rifkind, who played a pivotal role in successfully defending Time magazine against a $50 million libel suit filed by Ariel Sharon, the former Israeli general, defense minister and later prime minister, died on March 12 at his home in Manhattan. He was 88.

title: Philadelphia Zoo Welcomes Four Endangered Tortoise Hatchlings
description: Four endangered Western Santa Cruz Galápagos tortoises hatched at the Philadelphia Zoo.

title: Fate of the Filibuster Emerges as a Central Issue in Senate Budget Fight
description: Senator John Thune, Republican of South Dakota and the majority leader, has made preserving the institution of the Senate his signature issue since Day 1. And in his inaugural speech as leader in January, he called the filibuster “the Senate rule that today has perhaps the greatest impact on preserving the founders’ vision of the U.S. Senate.”

title: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, April 5, 2025
description: Can you sort 8 historical events?

title: Sandra Day O’Connor Was Wrong About Electing Judges
description: After retiring from the Supreme Court in 2006, Justice Sandra Day O’Connor devoted her remaining active years to rescuing the process of choosing judges from the grip of partisan politics. Despite having run successfully for judicial office herself, she believed that judicial selection should be divorced from raising money and glad-handing voters.

title: Swiss Indignant to Make the Top 10 of Trump’s Tariffs List
description: Of all the countries that expected to be immune to President Trump’s tariffs, Switzerland was at the top of the list.

title: 16 States Sue to Restore N.I.H. Funding
description: California, Massachusetts and 14 other states sued the Trump administration on Friday for withholding grant funding from public health and medical research institutions, cuts that have forced universities to curtail research and to delay the hiring of new staff.

title: Trump Administration Is Ordered to Return Migrant Deported to El Salvador
description: A federal judge gave the Trump administration until the end of Monday to return to the United States a Maryland man who was inadvertently deported to El Salvador last month despite a court order allowing him stay in the country.

title: A Cake With Nothing to Hide
description: In 2013, I baked 400 dried-apple hand pies, with a touch of cream and black pepper, per my nearly 200-year-old Appalachian family recipe, and boxed them individually with a hearty slice of coconut cake. This was for the now-infamous cake-vs.-pie debate at the Southern Foodways Alliance Symposium in Oxford, Miss. I was not part of the debate, simply a neutral party tempting the audience with a little pink box filled with my rendition of both.

title: Theodore McCarrick, Cardinal Defrocked Over Sex Abuse, Dies at 94
description: Theodore E. McCarrick, the former archbishop of Washington and the highest American prelate of the Roman Catholic Church to be accused of sexually abusing minors and seminarians — a charge that stripped him of his ministry, his place in the College of Cardinals and his priesthood, reducing him to the status of a layman — has died. He was 94.

title: Can Rich Parents Make Special Requests at a Public School?
description: My children attend a public elementary school in one of the country’s largest school systems. The school is notably diverse; more than 40 percent of the students are low-income, and nearly 10 percent live in temporary housing, while a sizable minority come from upper income brackets and live in million-dollar homes. The school has a mix of Latino, Black, Asian and white students. Some parents did not graduate from high school, while others have Ph.D.s, J.D.s or M.D.s.

title: Boston’s King of Couches Relinquishes His Crown
description: Bostonians like to brag about their celebrities with big personalities — David Ortiz, Mindy Kaling, Mark Wahlberg, to name a few. And then there’s Eliot Tatelman of Jordan’s Furniture.

title: American Tourist Arrested After Trying to Film Isolated Tribe and Offer Diet Coke
description: An American tourist set off alone last week on an inflatable boat for the remote island of North Sentinel in the Indian Ocean. He had packed a Diet Coke and a coconut as an offering for the highly isolated tribe that lives there, and had brought along a GoPro camera in hopes of filming the encounter, the Indian police said.

title: A Miracle Underground: Sean Duffy Rides the Subway. (He Survived.)
description: For weeks, Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy has derided the New York City subway, repeatedly making fear-mongering assertions that the nation’s biggest transit system is unsafe.

title: Investors Recoil From Trump’s Pledge to Remake the Global Economy
description: Investors around the globe this week sent President Trump a clear message about his new tariff policy, announced triumphantly as a remaking of the economic order.

title: Private School Diversity Events Are Canceled Amid Government Crackdown
description: A prominent private schools group will not hold two decades-old conferences related to diversity this year, a notable move amid the federal government’s crackdown on equity and inclusion programs.

title: Colum McCann on the Surprising Drama of Undersea Cables
description: In his new novel, “Twist,” the National Book Award-winning Irish writer Colum McCann tells the story of a journalist deep at sea in more ways than one: A man adrift, he accepts a magazine assignment to write about the crews who maintain and repair the undersea cables that transmit all of the world’s information. Naturally, the assignment becomes more treacherous and psychologically fraught than he had anticipated. On this week’s episode, McCann tells the host Gilbert Cruz how he became interested in the topic of information cables and why the story resonated for him at multiple levels.

title: Justices Are Asked to Keep Nationwide Pause on Trump’s Birthright Citizenship Order
description: Immigrant groups and leaders of 22 Democratic-led states pushed back sharply on Friday against the Trump administration’s request that the Supreme Court lift a temporary nationwide ban blocking the president’s order to end birthright citizenship for the children of undocumented immigrants and foreign residents.

title: Republican Plan to Kill California’s E.V. Policies Hits Senate Snag
description: Republicans in Congress cannot use an obscure legislative maneuver to stop California’s ban on the sale of new gasoline-powered cars by 2035, the Senate parliamentarian ruled on Friday.

title: Tracy Chapman Wants to Speak for Herself
description: “I haven’t really done press in a long time,” Tracy Chapman said as she settled onto a bench in the courtyard of San Francisco’s stately Fairmont Hotel earlier this week, wearing a black beanie over her pulled-back, gray-flecked dreads.

title: States Challenge Trump’s Effort to Dismantle Library Agency
description: A coalition of 21 state attorneys general filed a lawsuit on Friday challenging the Trump administration’s efforts to dismantle the federal agency charged with supporting the nation’s libraries.

title: Head of African American Museum Departs as Trump Targets Smithsonian
description: Kevin Young, the director of the Smithsonian’s National Museum of African American History and Culture, stepped down on Friday after four years in the role, the museum said.

title: Jean Van Leeuwen, 87, Dies; Wrote ‘Oliver Pig’ Series of Children’s Books
description: Jean Van Leeuwen, an award-winning children’s book author whose popular characters included the wholesome siblings Oliver and Amanda Pig and an adventurous, cocksure mouse named Marvin the Magnificent, died on March 3 at her home in Chappaqua, N.Y. She was 87.

title: Supreme Court Lets Trump Suspend Grants to Teachers
description: The Supreme Court on Friday let the Trump administration temporarily suspend $65 million in teacher-training grants that the government contends would promote diversity, equity and inclusion initiatives, an early victory for the administration in front of the justices.

title: Martha Stewart and Jason Wu Under a Weeping Willow
description: Just before 6 p.m. on a balmy Thursday evening, the floral designer Emily Thompson stood on a street in Manhattan’s flower district, examining a massive spray of weeping willow sprigs.

title: Farmers Brace for Significant Losses in a New Trade War
description: The U.S. agricultural industry is bracing for the potential of tens of billions of dollars in losses after China on Friday announced a 34 percent retaliatory tariff on imports from the United States.

title: More Than 500 Law Firms Back Perkins Coie in Fight With Trump
description: More than 500 law firms on Friday threw their support behind some of their embattled peers, declaring that President Trump’s recent crackdown on the law firm industry poses “a grave threat to our system of constitutional governance and to the rule of law itself.”

title: Senate Wades Into All-Night Vote-a-Thon as Republicans Seek to Pass Budget Plan
description: The Senate plunged into a political showdown over President Trump’s domestic agenda that began Friday night and crept into Saturday morning, as Democrats forced dozens of votes during an overnight session to protest Republicans’ push to deliver “one big beautiful bill” of spending and tax cuts.

title: Stocks Keep Falling
description: China struck back today against President Trump’s new tariffs, promising to match his plan to place a 34 percent fee on goods from China with its own 34 percent tariff on imports from the U.S. The escalation intensified fears of an economic slowdown and helped fuel a further sell-off in U.S. stocks.

title: Map: Earthquake Near Papua New Guinea Prompts Tsunami Alert
description: View the location of the quake’s epicenter and shake area.

title: Ted Cruz and Other Senate Republicans Question Trump’s Tariffs
description: Some Republican senators on Capitol Hill, including one of President Trump’s most ardent supporters, have signaled their uneasiness to the sweeping global tariffs that the president announced this week and that sent global markets reeling.

title: Loomer’s Role in Firings Shows Rising Sway of Fringe Figures on Trump
description: Laura Loomer had President Trump’s full attention.

title: How Guantánamo Bay Figures in the Trump Immigration Crackdown
description: Two months after President Trump ordered his administration to prepare the U.S. Navy base at Guantánamo Bay for up to 30,000 migrants, about 400 migrants have been held there at a cost to taxpayers of more than $40 million.

title: Judge Orders Tufts Student’s Detention Case Moved to Vermont
description: A federal judge ordered Friday that the case to free Rumeysa Ozturk, a Tufts student from Turkey, from immigration detention should be moved to a court in Vermont, denying a government demand to hold the proceedings in Louisiana, where she is being held.

title: Trump Rejects Biden Plan to Expand Medicare Coverage for Obesity Drugs
description: The Trump administration on Friday rejected a Biden plan that would have required Medicare and Medicaid to cover obesity drugs and expanded access for millions of people.

title: Los Angeles County Plans to Pay $4 Billion to Settle Sex Abuse Claims
description: Los Angeles County has agreed to pay a staggering $4 billion to settle sex abuse claims from generations of children in its juvenile detention and foster care systems in what lawyers said would be the largest payout of its kind in U.S. history.

title: A Federal Lab That Tracked Rising S.T.I.s Has Been Shuttered
description: Drug-resistant gonorrhea, a form of the widespread sexually transmitted infection, is considered an urgent health threat worldwide. The United States has just lost its ability to detect it.

title: What Might Europe’s Fines Against X Mean for Musk?
description: Elon Musk’s close relationship with President Trump may well end up shielding him from the 32 continuing investigations, pending complaints or enforcement actions against his companies in the United States. But something else appears to be happening for Musk in Europe.

title: How Tariffs Are Hitting Digital Commerce Companies
description: This year was supposed to be a banner moment for digital commerce companies.

title: Vandalism of Muslim Prayer Room at N.Y.U. Is Investigated as Hate Crime
description: A prayer room used by Muslim students at New York University was struck by vandals who etched and drew graffiti on the walls and soaked Islamic prayer mats with urine, according to N.Y.U. officials and members of the university’s Muslim community.

title: Read the Naval Academy’s list of removed books
description: The Navy released the titles of 381 books that were removed from the U.S. Naval Academy’s Nimitz Library on the Annapolis, Md., campus this week because their subject matter was seen as being related to so-called diversity, equity and inclusion topics.

title: New York Warns Trump It Will Not Comply With Public School D.E.I. Order
description: The New York State Education Department on Friday issued a defiant response to the Trump administration’s threats to pull federal funding from public schools over certain diversity, equity and inclusion programs, a remarkable departure from the conciliatory approach of other institutions in recent weeks.

title: Obama Calls for Universities to Stand Up for Core Values
description: Former President Barack Obama, in a campus speech on Thursday, urged universities to resist attacks from the federal government that violate their academic freedom.

title: These Are the 381 Books Removed From the Naval Academy Library
description: Maya Angelou’s seminal autobiography, “I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings,” and books on the Holocaust were included on the Navy’s list of 381 books that were removed from the U.S. Naval Academy’s Nimitz Library on the Annapolis, Md., campus this week because their subject matter was seen as being related to so-called diversity, equity and inclusion topics.

title: Video Shows Aid Workers Killed in Gaza Under Gunfire Barrage, With Ambulance Lights On
description: A video, discovered on the cellphone of a paramedic who was found along with 14 other aid workers in a mass grave in Gaza in late March, shows that the ambulances and fire truck that they were traveling in were clearly marked and had their emergency signal lights on when Israeli troops hit them with a barrage of gunfire.

title: Why the Central U.S. Is Experiencing Severe Flooding
description: Meteorologists say flooding could be catastrophic this week in parts of the country. Judson Jones, a meteorologist and reporter for The New York Times, describes how the ground is being dangerously saturated by a series of storms.

title: Man Employs A.I. Avatar in Legal Appeal, and Judge Isn’t Amused
description: Jerome Dewald sat with his legs crossed and his hands folded in his lap in front of an appellate panel of New York State judges, ready to argue for a reversal of a lower court’s decision in his dispute with a former employer.

title: Having Ears Pricked
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Weekend solvers are likely familiar with Rafael Musa by now: He has been making crosswords for The New York Times since 2022, but he already has a byline on 16 prior grids that all have run on Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays. All were tough, in other words, and many were made in collaboration with other constructors who excel at challenging experienced solvers.

title: ‘White Lotus’ Takes On Touchy Subjects. The Southern Accent Is One of Them.
description: Viewers have obsessed over whether the accents in Season 3 were credible, or another atrocious attempt by Hollywood to replicate a Southern dialect.

title: Judge Permanently Bars N.I.H. From Limiting Medical Research Funding
description: A federal judge permanently barred the Trump administration on Friday from limiting funding from the National Institutes of Health that supports research at universities and academic medical centers, restoring billions of dollars in grant money but setting up an almost certain appeal.

title: The Hidden Decisions Behind Trump’s Tariff Formula
description: Small changes in the math can mean big differences: Switzerland’s tariffs could be much lower. Bermuda’s could be way higher. And Australia could have no tariffs at all.

title: Quote of the Day: After ‘Adolescence,’ a Teen Handles School and Fame
description: “That’s it. That kid was like Robert De Niro.”

title: Corrections: April 5, 2025
description: A picture caption with an article on Monday about Bryan Bailey, a sheriff in Mississippi who is accused of benefiting from inmate labor, misidentified the location where several men were building a deck. It was the home of Christian Dedmon, a former deputy sheriff, not the home of Mr. Bailey.
