title: Stocks Fall as Tariff Pause Fails to Quell Wall Street’s Worries
description: The stock market resumed its slide on Thursday, as the White House clarified that Chinese imports would face a tariff of 145 percent, prompting renewed investor angst over an escalating trade war between the world’s two largest economies.

title: Gerald Luss, Master of Midcentury-Modern Design, Dies at 98
description: Gerald Luss, whose sophisticated designs for Manhattan high-rise offices and lush layouts for residential interiors helped define the look known as midcentury modern — particularly his plan for the Time-Life offices, which was so true to its era that it provided the model for the sets of “Mad Men” — died on April 1 at his home in Manhattan. He was 98.

title: Andrew Tate Is Accused of Rape and Threatening a Woman With Gun in U.K. Lawsuit
description: Andrew Tate, the online influencer known for his misogynistic views, has been accused of raping two women and threatening one of them with a gun, in a claim filed in Britain’s High Court.

title: Trump May Seek Judicial Oversight of Columbia, Potentially for Years
description: The Trump administration may seek to have a federal judge enforce any deal it reaches with Columbia University in an arrangement that could ensure that the White House has a hand in the school’s dealings for years to come, according to four people with knowledge of the matter.

title: ‘Her Majesty’ Is Glamorous and Salty Fun
description: The Spanish comedy “Her Majesty,” on Amazon Prime Video (in Spanish, with subtitles), is set within the fictional, scandal-plagued royal family of Spain. It centers on Princess Pilar (Anna Castillo), who probably should have outgrown her party-girl ways by now. She can be surly and resentful, and she isn’t as comfortable in the public eye as she’ll need to be. She’s no dummy: She knows she’ll be queen one day. But she has to step into the role much earlier than she expected.

title: Producing Something This Stupid Is the Achievement of a Lifetime
description: You might have seen the various data points suggesting that Americans are losing their ability to reason.

title: Friday Briefing: A Worsening Trade War
description: U.S. stocks tumbled yesterday as Treasury bonds began to sell off again, oil prices dropped and the stocks of Big Tech companies like Apple and Nvidia fell. Together, the signs pointed to a souring mood as investors assessed the worsening trade war with China.

title: Trump Close to Winning Concessions From More Law Firms
description: President Trump is planning to announce new deals with several of the nation’s top law firms requiring them to offer legal support for some of his favored causes, according to people with knowledge of the matter.

title: Markets ‘Hanging on Every Little Bit of Tariff Talk’
description: Joe Rennison covers financial markets for The New York Times. He does not try to predict them.

title: If It Exists, Someone Has Left It in an Uber
description: It may surprise some to learn that New York is the most forgetful city when it comes to ride shares. So says Uber, which has released its ninth annual Lost & Found Index — a hilarious, surprising and occasionally gross list of stuff riders left behind in cars last year. (Miami, Chicago, Los Angeles and Washington, D.C., were close behind New York in obliviousness.)

title: Trump, Offering Few Details, Insists ‘Everybody’ Wants to Make a Deal With the U.S.
description: A day after President Trump capitulated on his global reciprocal tariffs, he and Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick insisted that one country after another was coming to them to make deals to avoid further economic pain.

title: Tariff Angst Rises
description: The exuberance that spread yesterday across Wall Street after President Trump dialed down his expansive tariffs did not last long. The U.S. stock market fell sharply today, with the S&P 500 down 3.5 percent.

title: Do You Receive Health Care at the V.A.? We’d Like to Hear from You.
description: The New York Times is working on a series of stories about the experiences of veterans seeking health care through the Department of Veterans Affairs. The United States has promised to care for those who served, and we would like to examine whether that promise is being upheld amid job cuts and other policy changes in Washington.

title: Dismissed Players Take Aim at New York Philharmonic Misconduct Inquiry
description: Two musicians who were fired by the New York Philharmonic filed amended complaints against the orchestra on Thursday that assert they were wrongfully dismissed and that an inquiry by the ensemble had been biased against them.

title: Boston’s Museum of Fine Arts Names Next Director
description: The Museum of Fine Arts, Boston named Pierre Terjanian its next director and chief executive after a seven-month international search, museum officials said on Thursday.

title: In Cabinet Meeting, Musk Seems to Drastically Lower DOGE’s Savings Goal
description: While stumping for Donald J. Trump during the 2024 presidential campaign, Elon Musk said he could cut $2 trillion from the federal budget. After Mr. Trump took office and placed Mr. Musk in charge of the budget-slashing so-called Department of Government Efficiency, Mr. Musk lowered that projection by half, to $1 trillion in the upcoming fiscal year.

title: Phoenix Hits 100 Degrees as Southwest Swelters in Spring Heat
description: Phoenix hit a scorching 100 degrees Fahrenheit on Thursday, notching the city’s first triple-digit temperature of 2025 nearly a month before it typically reaches that high.

title: Joan Brown Campbell Dies at 93; Led Largest Ecumenical Body in U.S.
description: When Joan Campbell invited the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. to speak at her all-white church in the Cleveland suburbs in 1965, she had no idea of the furor it would cause.

title: Michael Hurley, a Singer Both Eccentric and Inspirational, Dies at 83
description: Michael Hurley, a singer and songwriter whose music — an idiosyncratic kind of folk mixed with a variety of other styles — made him a revered elder to younger artists like Cat Power, Devendra Banhart and the band Yo La Tengo, died on April 1 in Portland, Ore. He was 83.

title: Trump Escalates Use of Official Power to Intimidate and Punish His Perceived Foes
description: President Trump’s first-term efforts to spur law enforcement officials to pursue his political enemies were haphazard, informal and often hashed out in private.

title: Stunt Design Will Be Honored at the Academy Awards
description: There will soon be a new category at the Oscars: achievement in stunt design.

title: E.P.A. Is Said to Plan Deep Cuts to Greenhouse Gas Reporting Program
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has ordered the virtual elimination of a 15-year-old federal program that requires thousands of power plants, oil refineries, cement factories and other large industrial facilities to publicly report their greenhouse gas emissions, according to two people briefed on the decision.

title: Supreme Court Sides With Wrongly Deported Migrant
description: The Supreme Court on Thursday instructed the government to take steps to return a Salvadoran migrant it had wrongly deported to a notorious prison in El Salvador.

title: Helicopters Pack New York’s Skies, Despite Years of Noise and Air Pollution Complaints
description: Every year, tens of thousands of tourist helicopter flights depart from heliports in and around New York City. These tours, which generally cost several hundred dollars, advertise seeing many of the city’s iconic sights from above — Central Park, One World Trade Center, the Statue of Liberty — in as little as 15 minutes.

title: More European Opera Houses Welcome Back Anna Netrebko

description: Large plumes of smoke billowed into the air after a plane crashed in Boca Raton, Fla., on Friday morning.

title: Pope Makes Surprise Visit to St. Peter’s Basilica
description: Pope Francis made an unexpected visit to St. Peter’s Basilica on Thursday, wearing civilian clothes.

title: Pope Makes a Surprise Visit — and Style Statement — in St. Peter’s
description: For a pope known for unexpected gestures, Francis’ brief swing through St. Peter’s Basilica on Thursday might be the most audacious yet — at least in his attire.

title: May You Listen to ‘Interesting Times’
description: This week’s newsletter is a brief advertisement: As of this week, I have a new show, “Interesting Times,” with fresh episodes every Thursday, and I want to encourage you to subscribe.

title: Europe Moves to Shield Itself From Trade War Fallout
description: As the fallout from President Trump’s rewiring of global trade sets in across Europe, governments are putting in place billions of euros’ worth of “tariff shields” to protect their economies, companies and workers from uncertainty and the growing prospect of a recession.

title: Gov. Kim Reynolds of Iowa Won’t Seek Re-election, Setting Up Open Race
description: Kim Reynolds, the Republican governor of Iowa, announced on Friday that she would not seek re-election in 2026, setting up the first open race for the state’s top office in years.

title: Review: Dance Theater of Harlem, Reshaped and Back at City Center
description: When Robert Garland was chosen to take over as the artistic director of Dance Theater of Harlem in 2023, it was the ultimate inside hire. After performing with the company for 13 years, he spent more than 20 as its resident choreographer and the director of its school. The choice seemed to promise continuity, and so far, continuity is what Garland has delivered.

title: What to Know About Who Pays the Higher Costs of Trump’s Tariffs
description: President Trump’s latest tariffs are about to become an unavoidable and expensive reality for American businesses and for people who rely on foreign goods.

title: Miami Art Dealer Is Charged With Selling Fraudulent Warhols
description: A Miami art dealer was indicted on charges that he sold fraudulent Andy Warhols to collectors and provided them with fake invoices and forged authentication documents to make them appear legitimate.

title: ‘This is Not Normal’: Trump’s Tariffs Upend the Bond Market
description: The bedrock of the financial system trembled this week, with government bond yields rising sharply as the chaotic rollout of tariffs shook investors’ faith in the pivotal role played by the United States in the financial system.

title: Trump’s New Way to Kill Regulations: Because I Say So
description: President Trump this week directed 10 federal agencies — including the Environmental Protection Agency, the Energy Department and the Nuclear Regulatory Commission — to implement a novel procedure to scrap a wide array of longstanding energy and environmental regulations.

title: Top U.S. Prosecutor in New Jersey, a Trump Loyalist, Targets Governor
description: The top federal prosecutor in New Jersey said she had directed lawyers in her office to investigate the state’s Democratic governor and attorney general over a statewide policy that limits how much help local police can provide federal immigration officers.

title: Song of the Week: Who Is Tate McRae?
description: The singer’s “Sports Car” is a hit, but why does it sound so familiar? Jon Caramanica explains from his car in the latest “Popcast” song of the week video.

title: Trump Administration Delays Plan to Limit Pricey Bandages
description: The Trump administration announced Friday it would delay the implementation of a Biden-era rule meant to restrict coverage of unproven and costly bandages known as skin substitutes.

title: Who’s In and Who’s Out at the Naval Academy’s Library?
description: Gone is “I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings,” Maya Angelou’s transformative best-selling 1970 memoir chronicling her struggles with racism and trauma.

title: George Bell, Considered the Tallest Man in America, Dies at 67
description: George Bell, who at 7-foot-8-inches was called the tallest man in the United States, died on March 19 in Durham, N.C. He was 67.

title: What Is Actually the Point of Treating the N.I.H. Like This?
description: By the time their spending accounts were reactivated on Thursday, some scientists at the National Institutes of Health said they were running on fumes.

title: Fed Under Pressure as Inflation Expectations Surge
description: Federal Reserve officials have had one clear message since President Trump sharply escalated the global trade war this month. Keeping inflation expectations in check as price pressures rise is their No. 1 priority.

title: New York Helicopter Crash Recalls Another. And Another.
description: The helicopter has been a fixture in New York City for decades.

title: Alice Tan Ridley, Subway Singer on ‘America’s Got Talent,’ Dies at 72
description: Alice Tan Ridley, who rose to fame after decades singing for tips in the New York City subway with an unexpected run in the television show “America’s Got Talent,” died on March 25 in New York City. Ms. Ridley, who was the mother of the Oscar-nominated actress Gabourey Sidibe, was 72.

title: Ann Arbor Wants to Build Its Own Renewable-Energy Grid
description: The Climate Fix is our twice-a-month guide to the most important solutions to climate change across the world. Have comments about what we should cover? Email us at climateforward@nytimes.com.

title: Investors Seeking Safety Look to German Government Bonds
description: Germany has long taken flak from Wall Street and financial capitals around Europe for the extreme fiscal conservatism that has kept the country’s debt levels low. But as global markets convulsed this week, investors rewarded Germany’s caution by snapping up its government bonds, which are known as bunds.

title: Air Force Academy Stops Considering Class Diversity in Admissions Process
description: The Air Force Academy has stopped taking the race, gender or ethnicity of applicants into consideration, the Justice Department stated in a filing Friday responding to a lawsuit that accused the institution of discrimination for making class diversity a factor in its admissions process.

title: Pulp, Stereolab and Turnstile Return: Hear 10 New Songs
description: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes) and at Apple Music here, and sign up for The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.

title: ‘Yellowjackets’ Season 3 Finale Recap: The Wilderness Is Hungry
description: We’ve made it back to the beginning of “Yellowjackets.”

title: White House Plan Calls for NOAA Research Programs to Be Dismantled
description: Trump administration officials are recommending the elimination of the scientific research division at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, according to internal documents obtained by The New York Times and several people with knowledge of the situation.

title: ‘The Great Gatsby’ Is 100, and as Fresh as Ever
description: A century after “The Great Gatsby” was first published, F. Scott Fitzgerald’s slender novel about a mysterious, lovelorn millionaire living and dying in a Long Island mansion has become among the most widely read American fictions — and also among the most analyzed and interpreted. As the Book Review’s A.O. Scott wrote in a recent essay about the book’s centennial: “What we think about Gatsby illuminates what we think about money, race, romance and history. How we imagine him has a lot to do with how we see ourselves.”

title: Justice Dept. Lobbies for Release of Ex-F.B.I. Informant Accused of Lying About Bidens
description: The Justice Department, in an abrupt reversal, asked a federal judge late Thursday to release a former F.B.I. informant from prison pending appeal of his conviction on charges that he peddled misleading claims seized on by Trump allies to falsely accuse the Biden family of taking bribes.

title: How Snow Becomes Deadly
description: This season, more than 20 people died in avalanches in the U.S. Can mountains be safer?

title: Con Artists Scamming London Tourists Meet Their Match: Batman and Robin
description: Batman and Robin have taken a break from fighting crime in Gotham City to swoop on low-level scammers swindling tourists in the center of London.

title: From ‘The Last of Us’ to ‘The Walking Dead,’ How Well Do You Know Your TV Zombies?
description: “The Last of Us” returns on Sunday, the latest in TV’s lumbering horde of zombie shows. Can you tell one from another?

title: Trump Will End Temporary Protections for Afghans and Cameroonians
description: The Trump administration will end temporary protections for more than 10,000 people from Afghanistan and Cameroon, putting them on track for deportation in May and June, Department of Homeland Security officials said on Friday.

title: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, April 12, 2025
description: Can you sort 8 historical events?

title: A Tragic End to a Helicopter Pilot’s New Adventure
description: “Living the dream.”

title: Stocks Post Gain for the Week, but Investors Remain Anxious
description: Stocks on Wall Street ended a volatile week with a bounce on Friday, while government bond markets continued to signal investor worry about the impact of new import taxes, as China raised its tariffs on American-made products to 125 percent.

title: Investigation Into Helicopter Crash Just Getting Underway
description: Recovery crews were searching on Friday for the scattered wreckage of a sightseeing helicopter that appeared to break apart over the Hudson River the previous day before slamming into the water, killing all six people on board.

title: People Flee Eastern Gaza City After New Israeli Evacuation Orders
description: Since the collapse of the cease-fire in March, Israel has issued a succession of evacuation orders across Gaza, covering roughly half of the territory, displacing thousands of Palestinians.

title: Kennedy Accuses F.D.A. of Drug Industry Influence That Barred Alternative Remedies
description: In a speech broadcast to the Food and Drug Administration’s Maryland campus on Friday morning, Robert F. Kennedy Jr. introduced himself as the nation’s health secretary with a meandering speech touching on everything from birds of prey to pollution in Lake Erie to the C.I.A.

title: Immigration Judge Rules Khalil Can Be Deported, but Legal Hurdles Remain
description: An immigration judge in Louisiana found on Friday that the Trump administration could deport Mahmoud Khalil, granting the government an early victory in its efforts to crack down on pro-Palestinian demonstrations on U.S. college campuses.

title: Elected Official Is Among Dozens Charged in a Mob-Linked Gambling Case
description: A local elected official is among nearly 40 people charged with racketeering and other crimes connected to an illegal gambling ring run by members of the Lucchese organized crime family, New Jersey’s attorney general said on Friday.

title: Five More Big Law Firms Reach Deals With Trump
description: Five more prominent law firms facing potential punitive action by President Trump reached deals on Friday with the White House to provide a total of $600 million in free legal services to causes supported by the president.

title: A President Obsessed With Water Pressure? On Netflix and in the White House.
description: This week, as the global economy struggled to adjust to whipsawing tariff policies, President Trump signed an executive order to address another national crisis: weak shower head pressure.

title: Suzanne Rand, Half of a Once-Popular Comedy Team, Dies at 75
description: Suzanne Rand, who worked with John Monteith in a comedy team that was often compared to the groundbreaking Mike Nichols and Elaine May — and that, like them, became the stars of a two-person Broadway show — died on April 2 in Manhattan. She was 75.

title: See the Moments Leading Up to the Nightclub Roof Collapse in Santo Domingo
description: Video taken at the scene shows debris was already falling from the ceiling of the Jet Set nightclub before it caved in.

title: Judge Declines to Block Immigration Enforcement Operations in Places of Worship
description: A federal judge on Friday declined to block the Trump administration from carrying out detention and deportation operations in houses of worship, finding that a coalition of more than two dozen religious organizations had not made a clear case that their spaces and congregants had become common targets.

title: A Judge Ordered the U.S. to Detail Its Efforts to Return a Deported Man
description: A federal judge in Maryland ordered the Trump administration today to provide daily updates about its progress toward returning a migrant, Kilmar Armando Abrego Garcia, who administration officials acknowledge was wrongly deported nearly a month ago to a notorious prison in El Salvador.

title: Rick Levine, Who Gave Commercials Cinematic Flair, Dies at 94
description: Rick Levine, an award-winning television commercial director who brought a big-screen sensibility to the small screen with widely celebrated spots, like a Diet Pepsi Super Bowl ad from the 1980s featuring Michael J. Fox risking life and limb for love, died on March 11 at his home in Marina del Rey, Calif. He was 94.

title: Mangione Says U.S. Bid to Execute Him Is an Instagram Stunt
description: Lawyers for Luigi Mangione asked a federal court on Friday to bar prosecutors from seeking the death penalty against him, arguing that Attorney General Pam Bondi’s recently announced decision to do so was “explicitly and unapologetically political.”

title: The 12 Best Things We Saw at Salone Del Mobile
description: This year’s Salone del Mobile furniture fair, which took place this week in Milan, fell much earlier in April than usual. But that didn’t spare visitors from the sneezing fits the city’s springtime pollen shed can bring — or from the long lines and late nights that are now part of the event, which in recent years has become even bigger than the city’s fashion week. There was plenty of chatter about how shifting tariffs might affect the industry but, in all other ways, the fair was business as usual, with big design brands launching new projects and fashion houses getting in on the action with homewares collections or — in some cases this year — surprising, experimental collaborations. Below, a dozen projects that stood out.

title: Thousands of Voters Must Verify Information in Contested Election, N.C. Supreme Court Rules
description: In the latest twist in a prolonged legal battle over a North Carolina judicial seat, the State Supreme Court ruled on Friday that thousands of voters must fix issues with their ballots or risk having them tossed. The decision partially upheld a lower-court ruling and could lead to the November election being overturned.

title: My Girlfriend Keeps Looking Through My Phone. Should We Break Up?
description: I’m a 60-year-old man who has been divorced for eight years now. Since my divorce, I have not remarried and have ended two significant relationships because of behavioral and substance-use issues. Currently I’m in a relationship of 16 months with a recently separated woman. We don’t live together, but we spend most of our time together, functioning like a married couple. I’m employed in a higher-paying job and cover most of our expenses. When things are good, the relationship is deeply fulfilling and our romantic life is exceptional.

title: Joseph Boskin, Scholar of Humor and April Fools’ Prankster, Dies at 95
description: In March of 1983, a public relations official at Boston University asked Joseph Boskin, a scholar of humor in the history department, whether he knew anything about the origin of April Fools’ Day.

title: F.B.I. Suspends Employee on Patel’s So-Called Enemies List
description: The F.B.I. has suspended an analyst on Kash Patel’s so-called enemies list after Mr. Patel told lawmakers that the bureau under his leadership would stay out of the political fray and not punish employees for partisan reasons.

title: South Carolina Executes Second Inmate by Firing Squad
description: South Carolina executed another convicted murderer by firing squad on Friday night, the second such execution in the state.

title: Education Department Is Threatening to Cut All Federal Funding for Maine Schools
description: The Department of Education said on Friday that it was moving to cut off all federal funding for Maine’s public schools because the state had ignored President Trump’s executive order banning transgender athletes from girls’ sports teams.

title: Soulja Boy Is Ordered to Pay $4 Million in Sexual Assault Case
description: A jury in Los Angeles found the rapper Soulja Boy liable for sexual battery and assault, ordering him to pay $4 million to a woman who said that he became violent toward her as their once-professional relationship turned romantic, the woman’s lawyer said.

title: Military Judge Throws Out Sept. 11 Case Confession as Obtained Through Torture
description: A military judge on Friday threw out the confession that a man accused of conspiring in the Sept. 11 attacks made to federal agents in 2007 at Guantánamo Bay, ruling the statements were the product of a campaign of torture and isolation carried out by the C.I.A.

title: Pennsylvania Man Threatened to Kill Trump and Musk, U.S. Says
description: A Pennsylvania man was arrested this week after the authorities said he threatened to assassinate President Trump, Elon Musk and other government officials in comments that he posted on YouTube.

title: A New Policy Points Up a Musk Obsession
description: One hallmark of Elon Musk’s 12 weeks in government has been his focus on Social Security.

title: Freed From Prison by Trump and Now Facing the Prospect of Going Back
description: In the early hours of Feb. 15, Jonathan Braun, a violent felon granted clemency by President Trump, was agitated.

title: Efforts to Resentence Menendez Brothers Can Proceed, Judge Says
description: An effort to resentence the Menendez brothers can proceed after a Los Angeles judge cleared the way Friday for additional hearings next week.

title: Judge Says One DOGE Member Can Access Sensitive Treasury Dept. Data
description: A Manhattan federal judge ruled on Friday that one member of Elon Musk’s government efficiency program could have access to sensitive payment and data systems at the Treasury Department, as long as that person goes through appropriate training and files disclosures.

title: Get on the Board
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is a witty challenge from Jesse Cohn, who constructed two Friday grids for The Times last year (in the spring and the fall). Both were themeless, but Mr. Cohn also has a knack for interesting little patterns — mirrored entries with comedy in common, for example, or intersecting clues that involve scary animal sounds (or much scarier nukes). There are a lot of culinary elements in the puzzle as well, and I’m sure that solvers will notice other convergences.

title: Trump Directive Calls to Turn Border Land Into ‘Military Installation’
description: President Trump announced a plan on Friday to turn a narrow strip along the Mexican border in California, Arizona and New Mexico into a military installation as part of his effort to curtail illegal crossings.

title: White House Moves Obama Portrait to Make Room for New One of Trump
description: The Trump administration said on Friday that it had moved a portrait of former President Barack Obama in a White House hallway and replaced it with a pop-art painting of President Trump pumping his fist after the assassination attempt last year on the campaign trail in Butler, Pa.

title: Corrections: April 12, 2025
description: An article on Tuesday about Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s plans for the Indian Health Service misattributed a quote about Native Americans as political minorities. It was said by a Native leader who requested anonymity, not David Simmons, the government affairs and advocacy director for the National Indian Child Welfare Association.

title: After L.A. Fires, Edison Wants to Bury Power Lines in Altadena and Malibu
description: Southern California Edison, the electric utility whose equipment has been the focus of investigations into the deadly Eaton fire in Los Angeles County in January, said on Friday that it planned to bury more than 150 miles of power lines in fire-prone areas near Altadena and Malibu, Calif.

title: Appeals Court Scales Back Freeze on Firing Consumer Bureau Employees
description: A federal appeals panel on Friday halted parts of a district court judge’s injunction blocking the Trump administration’s effort to dismantle the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, allowing officials to move ahead with firing some agency employees.

title: Quote of the Day: No-Nonsense Heiress Leading New York’s Police
description: “Go out and fill out the hurt feelings report and leave it in the file. It’s called having a boss.”

title: Coup Leader Is Favored in Gabon Election After Ruling Family’s Fall
description: Voters in Gabon are set to pick their next president on Saturday, and on paper they have plenty of options: anti-French firebrands, a general who staged a coup, a tax inspector and a female candidate in this oil-rich Central African country.

title: Boeing Helped Power Russia’s Economy. Could It Return?
description: To hear President Vladimir V. Putin tell it, Russia’s economy has thrived despite Western sanctions, becoming more self-sufficient and reorienting toward new markets.

title: What to Know About U.S. Talks With Iran Over Its Nuclear Program
description: A brief handshake may be the most likely outcome from preliminary diplomatic talks set for Saturday between American and Iranian officials.

title: For Taiwan’s Small Exporters, the Uncertainty’s as Bad as the Tariffs
description: Since President Trump announced his wave of globe-spanning tariffs, Alex Tang has held morning pep talks with the dozen or so workers at his lathe-making factory in central Taiwan, preparing them for rocky times ahead. His business, like all of Taiwan’s export-dependent manufacturers, could be hit hard.

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.

description: Carmen Colon felt a sense of dread when her stepson did not respond to her texts.

title: Endorsement by Mayor Adams Appears to Lift Sales of Kash Patel’s Book
description: As mayor of New York City, Eric Adams faces uncertain re-election prospects this year. Should all not go according to plan, he may want to try his hand as a book promoter.

title: Before a Fatal Helicopter Crash, 2 Midair Breakdowns and Unpaid Bills
description: As federal investigators began the long job of examining what caused a sightseeing helicopter to crash into the Hudson River on Thursday, killing all six people on board, details began to emerge about the small company that made the doomed flight — and its operator’s checkered history.

title: Strong Winds Uproot Trees and Rattle Windows in Northern China
description: Beijing’s 22 million residents were asked to stay indoors on Saturday, as powerful winds swept across northern China. The winds toppled trees, disrupted travel and sports, and caused dust storms across the region.

title: Democrats Sue President Over Executive Order on Elections
description: Nearly every arm of the Democratic Party united in filing a lawsuit against the Trump administration on Monday night, arguing that a recent executive order signed by the president seeking to require documentary proof of citizenship and other voting reforms is unconstitutional.

title: Corrections: April 1, 2025
description: An article on Saturday about a powerful earthquake that struck central Myanmar on Friday inaccurately described the arrest of the leader of an armed group that has sought to protect Rohingya Muslims. The leader was arrested by the authorities in Bangladesh, not by Myanmar’s military.

title: Long Stretch
description: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

title: South Korea’s President Will Learn His Fate on Friday
description: Yoon Suk Yeol, the president of South Korea, who was impeached in December over his failed attempt to impose martial law, will learn Friday whether he will be formally removed from office or returned to power, the nation’s top court said Tuesday.

title: Pentagon Eliminates Lower Fitness Standards for Women in Combat Roles
description: The Pentagon this week ordered the elimination of lower physical fitness standards for women in combat units, a move that is likely to hinder the recruitment and retention of women in particularly dangerous military jobs.

title: Israel’s Military Strikes Near Beirut, Killing at Least 4
description: Israel launched airstrikes on the southern outskirts of Beirut on Tuesday for the second time in less than a week, killing at least four people and prompting fears that a fragile cease-fire could be unraveling.

title: Read the Alabama Judge’s Ruling
description: A federal judge ruled that Alabama could not prosecute doctors and reproductive health organizations for helping patients travel out of the state to obtain abortions.

title: ‘Glengarry Glen Ross’ Review: Caveat Emptor, Suckers!
description: Watch out for Richard Roma. Top man among the bottom feeders at a scammy Chicago real estate agency, he has a hypnotic come-on and a dizzying spiel. Identifying your vulnerabilities with forensic accuracy, he’ll lance them with a blunt needle. (“You think you’re queer?” he asks one mark. “I’m going to tell you something: We’re all queer.”) If it’s what you need, he’ll be the brother who thinks big on your behalf, who sees beyond your sad habit of safety to the rewards only risk can offer.

title: Johnson & Johnson Loses in Court Again in Bid to Settle Talc Cases
description: A federal bankruptcy judge in Houston on Monday rejected Johnson & Johnson’s request to approve a $9 billion settlement with tens of thousands of people who are suing the company over claims that its talcum powder products caused cancer.

title: Alabama Can’t Prosecute Those Who Help With Out-of-State Abortions, Judge Rules
description: Alabama cannot prosecute doctors and reproductive health organizations for helping patients travel out of the state to obtain abortions, a federal judge ruled on Monday.

title: Quote of the Day: A Chinese Truck Maker Wants the Green Light
description: “China doesn’t have to be the enemy forever, and not everyone from China has to be the enemy.”

title: The U.K. Government Wouldn’t Ban Phones in Schools. These Parents Stepped Up.
description: The idea of getting her eldest child a smartphone had long felt inevitable, said Daisy Greenwell. But by early last year, when her daughter was 8 years old, it filled her with dread. When she talked to other parents, “everyone universally said, ‘Yes, it’s a nightmare, but you’ve got no choice,’” recalled Ms. Greenwell, 41.

title: As Bangladesh Reinvents Itself, Islamist Hard-Liners See an Opening
description: The extremists began by asserting control over women’s bodies.

title: There’s No Party Like an Iftar Party for Bangladesh’s Aspiring Leaders
description: Around sunset during the Muslim fasting month of Ramadan, something remarkable happens in the Bangladeshi capital, Dhaka. The streets in this city of more than 10 million people, known for its hectic bustle and choking traffic, turn quiet and empty.

title: What to Watch in Today’s Big Elections in Wisconsin and Florida
description: Two states nearly a thousand miles apart will on Tuesday provide the best evidence yet of whether President Trump and his Republican allies maintain robust support or whether they face a growing backlash led by a re-energized Democratic Party.

title: Tuesday Briefing
description: Barring constitutional changes, President Trump cannot run for a third term. But he has floated the idea, publicly and otherwise, and said recently that he was “not joking” about it, though there’s no real evidence that it’s possible. (Top Republicans yesterday rejected the idea of amending the Constitution to allow it.)

title: The Clock Is Ticking for Taiwan
description: Taiwan’s cabdrivers are famously chatty, and after I settled into the back seat of a taxi in the island’s south recently, my cabby turned to me and cheerfully asked how my day was going, before abruptly declaring, “Ukraine today, Taiwan tomorrow.”

title: Israel Strikes Suburb in Beirut
description: The Israeli military said it was targeting a member of Hezbollah in an area near Lebanon’s capital that is a stronghold for the militant group.

title: China’s Military Exercises Around Taiwan Enter Second Day
description: China held military exercises around Taiwan for a second day on Wednesday, sending warships and fighter planes near the island in what Beijing said was a warning to its president, Lai Ching-te, after he called China a “foreign hostile force.”

title: Word of the Day: profusely
description: The word profusely has appeared in 71 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Jan. 1 in the guest essay “My Home Is Messy, and I Don’t Feel Bad About It” by KC Davis:

title: ‘They Are Beating a Child,’ Neighbor Told 911, Months Before Boy Died
description: In the middle of the night on Dec. 5, a woman in a Brooklyn apartment heard troubling sounds a few doors away: a boy wailing, a man shouting, women screaming and what seemed to be a hand striking bare skin.

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.

title: Princeton Senior, Accused of Assault During Protest, Is Found Not Guilty
description: Tension had been building at Princeton University as pro-Palestinian demonstrators occupied a white-columned, Greek Revival-style building at the center of campus and the police moved in. An angry crowd had surrounded a bus where two demonstrators were being held after officers led them out of the building.

title: A Bigger N.Y.P.D.? Mamdani Has a Different Idea.
description: In New York, playing to voters’ concerns about crime has become a popular strategy, successful enough that even left-leaning Democrats have embraced calls for more police officers.

title: Jon Stewart: Trump Is ‘Trying to Order Off-Menu From the Constitution’
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

title: U.S. Imposes Sanctions on Chinese and Hong Kong Officials for Pursuing Activists Abroad
description: The U.S. fired a new round of sanctions at China on Monday, targeting six high-level Chinese and Hong Kong officials over what it described as acts of transnational repression for their crackdown on pro-democracy activists in Hong Kong and on U.S. soil.

title: A Family Business Empire, and a Culture of ‘Keeping Your Mouth Shut’
description: Even in a frequently fogbound port city along the Atlantic Ocean, the billowing clouds of steam rising from Canada’s largest oil refinery over Saint John, New Brunswick, are impossible to miss.

title: Mum and Dad Won’t Toss the Rubbish. There’s a Llama in the Kitchen. Help!
description: The usual desire to kill your exasperating old parents — that’s the implied full title of Camilla Barnes’s wickedly delightful debut novel.

title: These Militias Refuse to Join Syria’s New Army
description: The trainer paced the grounds of a mountain enclave in southwestern Syria, shouting at dozens of new recruits as they drilled sprints between barricades made from old car tires.

title: Should You Always Be Sore After a Workout?
description: Q: If I’m not sore after I exercise, did it even count?

title: A Prison Death Highlights an L.G.B.T.Q. Crackdown in Russia
description: The travel agency offered tours aimed solely at men, and that was enough to attract the attention of the police enforcing new Russian laws that restrict the rights of gay people.

title: At the New Frick, Magicians Come Out of the Woodwork
description: Welcome to the latest installment of “This Old House,” the Henry Clay Frick mansion edition. The sumptuous 1914 Beaux-Arts residence is reopening to the public on April 17 after a $220 million, four-year renovation, and with a series of member events this week. For the first time in 90 years, visitors will be able to ascend the Grand Staircase to experience the family’s private rooms on the second floor, the velvet ropes whisked away.

title: Our Favorite Bathrooms
description: In the bathroom of the fashion executives Carlo Alberto Beretta and Jacopo Venturini’s Milan apartment, a stucco shell and glazed tiles that are original to the house, with William Morris wallpaper, exemplify Italy’s turn-of-the-20th-century Liberty style. Read more here.

title: A Victim of Childhood Rape Close-Reads Her Past
description: In December of last year, a court in Avignon, France, found 51 men guilty of raping 72-year-old Gisèle Pelicot, including her husband of 50 years, who repeatedly drugged and assaulted her, invited other men to join him and filmed their abuse. He was given the maximum sentence of 20 years in prison, and Pelicot emerged from the four-month trial, whose proceedings were open to the public, a feminist hero.

title: What’s So Hard About Building Trains?
description: Firemen from Highland Beach, Fla., were heading to a conference in Miami; a money manager was on his way to his office in Boca Raton. Families with young children wearing Mickey Mouse ears and toting Little Mermaid backpacks, filled the train’s sun-soaked four-seaters on their way to or from Disney cruises and various theme parks.

title: The Revolving Restaurant Is Back Again (and Again)
description: When your ears pop on the elevator ride up, that’s how you know you’ve arrived at the View, the revolving bar and restaurant on the 47th and 48th floors of the New York Marriott Marquis.

title: A Concept Album About Dennis Hopper? The Waterboys Made One.
description: In 1977, several years before Mike Scott founded the Waterboys, the band he still leads today, he started Jungleland. At the time, he was an 18-year-old obsessed with music and literature, living in Ayr, a seaside town on the west coast of Scotland. Jungleland wasn’t a band — it was a fanzine named after a Bruce Springsteen song in which Scott wrote about the artists that enthralled him, including the Clash, Richard Hell and the Sex Pistols.

title: Parenting in the Age of Social Media and — Help! — A.I.
description: The social psychologist Jonathan Haidt discusses the “parents’ revolution” on smartphones that his book “The Anxious Generation” has ignited.

title: The Case for Telling Total Strangers to Shut Up
description: I was raised by a movie talker. When I was a child, my dad and I went to our local theater every Wednesday to see whatever was out. If that week’s offering was pure schlock, my dad and I would yuk it up. His humor, complemented by an insider’s perspective afforded to him by a career as a writer and director, was incisive and perfect to me. Like a sidelined quarterback barking at the television on Super Bowl Sunday, he called out narrative inconsistencies or forced plot turns with ease, or pointed out actors’ tics that escaped less practiced eyes.

title: Professors Pushed Harvard to Resist Trump. Now Billions Are on the Line.
description: The Trump administration has turned campaign promises to target universities into devastating action, pulling hundreds of millions in federal funds from Columbia University and the University of Pennsylvania.

title: After a Slow Start, High-Speed Rail Might Finally Arrive in America
description: In 1965, President Lyndon B. Johnson signed a law — the High-Speed Ground Transportation Act — that seemed to pave the way for a national high-speed rail system in the United States. “An astronaut can orbit the earth faster than a man on the ground can get from New York to Washington,” he lamented at the time. Sixty years later, it still takes about three hours to travel between the two cities — a period about twice as long as a single orbit of the International Space Station.

title: In These Poems Life Is a Party, Complete With Designer Drugs
description: In his seminal “Letters to a Young Poet,” Rainer Maria Rilke encourages his long-distance apprentice to be as patient as possible with everything unsolved in his heart, to learn to love the questions themselves “like locked rooms and like books that are now written in a very foreign tongue.” “Do not now seek the answers,” he writes, “which cannot be given you because you would not be able to live them. And the point is, to live everything. Live the questions now. Perhaps you will then gradually, without noticing it, live along some distant day into the answer.”

title: How Trump’s Tariffs Are Hitting One Chinese Factory Owner: ‘We Are Helpless’
description: Women in blue cloth hairnets sew the finishing touches on plush pink piggies and orange stuffed foxes, before tossing them onto giant piles in Maria Liao’s factory in southern China. They will be boxed and shipped to the United States, where many of Ms. Liao’s clients are based.

title: Should Human Life Be Optimized?
description: Advances in genetic testing and artificial intelligence are changing what’s possible for those undergoing I.V.F. Are we ready for the future of fertility?

title: Martha Argerich, the Elusive, Enigmatic ‘Goddess’ of the Piano
description: The pianist Martha Argerich had just delivered an electrifying performance on a snowy night in northern Switzerland. Fans were lining up backstage for autographs, and friends were bringing roses and chrysanthemums to her dressing room.

title: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Disney+, Amazon, Max, Apple TV+ and More in April
description: Every month, streaming services add movies and TV shows to their libraries. Here are our picks for some of April’s most promising new titles. (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)

title: Trump Loves Tariffs. Do Americans?
description: Astead Herndon, a New York Times politics reporter and host of the podcast “The Run-Up,” unpacks what the voters and the polling say about President Trump’s signature economic policy: tariffs.

title: Who’s Coming Clean About Steroids?
description: At the Fit Club gym on the north side of Las Vegas, the fitness influencer Kenny Boulet approached strangers between sets of leg presses and upright rows and asked them the same question.

title: Trump’s Mantra From Schools to FEMA: ‘Move It Back to the States’
description: President Trump’s interest in closing down the Education Department was never front and center to any of his three White House campaigns, but his explanation for shuttering the agency has always remained consistent.

title: Why Old Friends Bring Out Our Worst Teenage Selves
description: “We’re still the same people we were in the 10th grade,” Carrie Coon’s character, Laurie, on the hit HBO series “The White Lotus,” tells her two friends. “It’s just funny,” she adds.

title: Will Trump’s Choice for Joint Chiefs Chairman Be Blunt or Hold His Tongue?
description: Lt. Gen. Dan Caine’s pocket-size copy of the Constitution is tattered and bound with green military tape.

title: I’m an Alum of Columbia and Paul, Weiss. There’s an Uncomfortable Lesson in Trump’s Tactics.
description: “Unhappy is the land that needs a hero,” wrote Bertolt Brecht in “Life of Galileo.”

title: Andrew Scott on ‘Vanya’: ‘Who Isn’t Sad?’
description: “I really believe that we all do contain multitudes,” Andrew Scott said on a Friday morning in March. Scott may contain more than most. An actor of unusual sensitivity and verve, he is starring, solo, in an Off Broadway production of Chekhov’s melancholy comedy “Uncle Vanya.” The title, like the cast list, has also been condensed, to just “Vanya.”

title: Want to Play a Game? Global Trade War Is the New Washington Pastime.
description: The world’s biggest powers were deep in a trade war. Economic losses from the tariffs that President Trump had imposed on most of the world, along with global retaliation, were accumulating. Jobs were being lost, inflation was ticking up and the world was both frustrated with and anxious about the United States.

title: What Are Your Favorite Things About Spring?
description: Spring is officially here. For many in the Northern Hemisphere, that means warmer temperatures, new blooms, a fresh wardrobe, holiday celebrations, baseball season, spring break and more.

title: ‘Our Kids Are the Least Flourishing Generation We Know Of’
description: This is an edited transcript of an episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.” You can listen to the conversation by following or subscribing to the show on the NYT Audio App, Apple, Spotify, Amazon Music, YouTube, iHeartRadio or wherever you get your podcasts.

title: Layer Your Lighting Design for Drama and Functionality
description: Lighting can have a dramatic effect on the way a room looks and feels. When designing a home, planning the lighting scheme is “beyond critical,” said Alex Miller, a partner at the New York-based architecture and lighting design firm Taylor and Miller. “Lighting is a very soulful thing,” he noted, which directly changes the way we perceive a space.

title: Trump Just Reached a Historic Milestone
description: We’ve gotten used to seeing a president’s first 100 days as a gauge of progress and a benchmark for history. (Thanks, Franklin Roosevelt.) To understand the early days of President Trump’s second term, however, when so much has happened so quickly, there is an alternative milestone to consider.

title: As Trump Stokes Uncertainty, the Fed Asks Businesses Where It Hurts
description: Chris Bergen, who runs a commercial greenhouse business in northern Minnesota, finds himself “walking a tightrope” roughly two months into President Trump’s second term. Acute uncertainty about how the administration’s trade and immigration policies will unfold and affect the economy has made him much more cautious about any expansion plans.

title: When Banksy Came to Red Hook and Made His Mark
description: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll find out about what happened to a 7,500-pound chunk of a wall with a Banksy installation from 2013. We’ll also get details on a request from Mayor Eric Adams’s lawyer for a federal judge to hurry a decision on whether to drop corruption charges against the mayor.

title: Amazon’s New Movie Strategy Starts With Theaters
description: Amazon’s movie strategy is finally ready for its close-up.

title: Pranks
description: Did you see the oil rigging prank going around TikTok last year? Influencers called up their loved ones and told them they had been invited on a trip, paid for by Exxon Mobil, to an oil rig off the coast of Texas. Those on the receiving end of the call (who were not in on the joke) had mixed reactions — some were supportive, some were just confused.

title: The Message Pete Hegseth Sends the Troops
description: Before setting foot in the Pentagon, Pete Hegseth had something to prove. He was confirmed as defense secretary by a vote of 51 to 50 — the narrowest margin in modern history — after facing withering allegations about excessive drinking, sexual assault and lack of relevant experience to lead the military, the federal government’s largest agency.

title: ‘Bottom Line Is That We Have Lost Control of Our Destiny’
description: Democrats are acutely aware of their political problems.

title: Democrats Have Problems. Turning Out for Special Elections Isn’t One of Them.
description: It can feel as if the Democratic Party has a lot of work to do before it is ready to win elections again. Its agenda appears exhausted. Its voters are disillusioned. Its politicians have struggled to muster vigorous opposition to President Trump.

title: Cory Booker Condemns Trump’s Policies in Longest Senate Speech on Record
description: Senator Cory Booker, his voice still booming after more than a day spent on the Senate floor railing against the Trump administration, on Tuesday night surpassed Strom Thurmond for the longest Senate speech on record, in an act of astonishing stamina that he framed as a call to action.

title: Connections Companion No. 661
description: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

title: Wordle Review No. 1,383
description: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

title: Is Elon Musk Buying Today’s Election in Wisconsin?
description: On paper, the election in Wisconsin on Tuesday is about who should control the state’s highest court. In reality, it has become a referendum on Elon Musk, his agenda in Washington and his willingness to flood American politics with his money.

title: The Most Expensive Judicial Race in U.S. History, and a Growing Demand for Ivermectin
description: On Today’s Episode:

title: Cory Booker Delivers Marathon Speech on Senate Floor
description: Senator Cory Booker, Democrat of New Jersey, spoke for more than 25 hours, criticizing the Trump administration’s policies on Social Security, education, health care and more.

title: Cutting Off NPR and PBS
description: There is no reason, Republicans say, for the government to fund NPR and PBS.

title: A Symbol of a City’s Rapid Growth Comes Crashing Down
description: It was marketed as a place with an “earthquake-resistant foundation.” The 12-story Sky Villa Condominium complex featured the largest rooftop bar in the central Myanmar city of Mandalay and a gym with state-of-the-art equipment.

title: High Stakes and Lack of Details Add to Trade War Jitters
description: President Trump likes a big splash, and he’s not holding back for Wednesday’s introduction of reciprocal tariffs on America’s trading partners: Expect a major announcement in the Rose Garden.

title: Hooters Files for Bankruptcy, but Its Restaurants Will Stay Open
description: Hooters, the restaurant chain known for its chicken wings, its all-female serving staff in revealing outfits and its slogan — “delightfully tacky, yet unrefined” — has filed for bankruptcy in a Texas court, the company announced on Monday.

title: Iceland Volcano Eruption Threatens Town
description: A volcano in southwestern Iceland erupted on Tuesday, endangering the town of Grindavik and prompting the closure of the popular Blue Lagoon tourist destination. It was the 11th eruption to shake the country’s Reykjanes Peninsula since 2021 as Iceland faces a period of intense geological activity.

title: Pope Francis’ Health Continues to Improve, Vatican Says
description: Pope Francis’ health has continued to improve in the week since he left the hospital after a weekslong stay, the Vatican said Tuesday.

title: Cornell Student Who Faced Deportation Says He Has Left U.S.
description: A British-Gambian Ph.D. student at Cornell University who had faced possible deportation after participating in pro-Palestinian protests said on Monday that he had left the United States.

title: SpaceX Puts Humans in Orbit Over Earth’s Poles for the First Time
description: A SpaceX rocket blasted off Monday night from Florida, the first trip to put humans into an orbit that takes them over both of Earth’s poles.

title: New York City Pension Funds Plan to Sue Tesla Over Musk’s DOGE Leadership
description: The head of New York City’s pension funds called for a shareholder lawsuit against Tesla, accusing Elon Musk, its chief executive, of causing the company’s shares to plunge because of his actions to slash spending and the federal work force as head of the Trump administration’s cost-cutting effort.

title: A Graphic Coat of Many Colors
description: When I saw Mindy Prugnaud out in the Greenwich Village section of Manhattan on a Friday afternoon in February, I was compelled to say hello. I just had to learn more about her marvelous coat.

title: Trump Announces Deal With Doug Emhoff’s Law Firm
description: President Trump announced Tuesday another deal with a law firm he had targeted for potential punishment, this time the one that employs Doug Emhoff, former Vice President Kamala Harris’s husband.

title: Netanyahu Drops Nominee for Spy Chief After Backlash
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel backed away from his nominee to lead Israel’s domestic intelligence service on Tuesday, after conservative allies attacked the candidate for criticizing President Trump and Israeli media reported that he had protested judicial overhauls pushed by the government.

title: U.S. Says Deportation of Maryland Man Was an ‘Administrative Error’
description: A Maryland man who was in the United States legally was deported to El Salvador and imprisoned there because of an “administrative error,” Trump administration officials said in a court filing on Monday, adding that American courts lacked the jurisdiction to have him released.

title: Weekly Student News Quiz: Earthquake, Security Breach, Baseball Season
description: Have you been paying attention to current events recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.

title: Mass Layoffs Hit Health Agencies That Track Disease and Regulate Food
description: The Trump administration laid off thousands of federal health workers on Tuesday in a purge that included senior leaders and top scientists charged with regulating food and drugs, protecting Americans from disease and researching new treatments and cures.

title: Three New Works of Theater to Share One Trait: Hope
description: Hope may seem daring in this age of angst and uncertainty, but it is at the heart of three major new works coming to the Fisher Center at Bard, including a musical adaptation of “Yentl the Yeshiva Boy,” the performing arts center announced on Tuesday.

title: Congress Wrote a Deportation Law to Be Used ‘Sparingly.’ Trump Has Other Ideas.
description: The Trump administration is asserting that it has broad power under a 1952 law to kick out foreign students who participated in pro-Palestinian protests. That statute says the secretary of state can deem noncitizens deportable for foreign policy reasons, and the secretary, Marco Rubio, made it clear recently that he had already used it to cancel hundreds of student visas.

title: Fatal Crash in China Puts Assisted Driving Tech Under Scrutiny
description: China’s Xiaomi, a consumer electronics giant turned automaker, said it was cooperating with a police investigation into a fatal crash involving one of its electric vehicles while the driver was using the car’s autonomous driving features.

title: Meet the Beatles! (The Movie Version, at Least.)
description: There has been no shortage of movies about the Beatles. But the director Sam Mendes is embarking on a project that stands apart for its ambition — four films, each from a different band member’s perspective — and now we know who will be playing the Fab Four.

title: After a Terminal Cancer Diagnosis, a Lawyer Seeks Revenge
description: For many people, being diagnosed with terminal cancer at the age of 40 might prompt an instant reassessment of priorities. For Hester, the narrator of Ariel Courage’s debut novel, “Bad Nature,” this means immediately quitting her job in Manhattan to drive across the country and murder her father.

title: Millions of Women Will Lose Access to Contraception as a Result of Trump Aid Cuts
description: The United States is ending its financial support for family planning programs in developing countries, cutting nearly 50 million women off from access to contraception.

title: Five Ingredients, Five Stars, No Joke
description: April Fools’ Day is a holiday that could really use a signature dish. The chef and author Rozanne Gold once wrote an article arguing for “culinary pranksterism” for April Fools’; she’d long collected surprising but wonderful recipes, like a chicken roasted inside a watermelon and cake baked in a shoe box (women’s size 9, 24 servings). A more literal but still delicious option for tonight: the fool, a heavenly English dessert that consists of mashed fruit and lightly sweetened whipped cream.

title: A Farmhouse Refuge From a Nazi Blitz Became His Forever Home
description: In November 1940, four children showed up after dark at a stone farmhouse in rural Pennsylvania. They arrived by car down a long dirt driveway. The headlights illuminated the tall elm trees surrounding the manor house, and the rooms inside were lit up brightly.

title: Trump Says He’s Settled on a Tariff Plan That Is Set to Take Effect Wednesday
description: President Trump has settled on a final plan for sweeping “reciprocal” tariffs, which are expected to take effect on Wednesday after he announces the details at an afternoon Rose Garden ceremony.

title: Shake-Up in China’s Auto Sector: Two Giants Are Discussing a Merger
description: Two of China’s biggest state-owned automakers are in advanced discussions to merge, in a deal that would create a formidable manufacturer of cars and military vehicles but could also create problems for their American and Japanese partners.

title: Why Italy Made It Harder to Become Italian
description: People of Italian descent have for decades been able to dig through their family trees, find an Italian ancestor and apply for citizenship to Italy, securing a powerful passport that allows them to enter more countries without a visa than travelers of almost any other nationality.

title: Prosecutors to Seek Death Penalty for Mangione, Bondi Says
description: Attorney General Pam Bondi said on Tuesday that she would seek the death penalty for Luigi Mangione, who was charged with murdering a UnitedHealthcare executive in Manhattan last year, part of a push to revive the widespread use of capital punishment in federal cases.

title: ‘I Am Disgusted’: Le Pen Voters Voice Outrage Over Her Conviction
description: When the verdict from a Paris criminal court flashed across screens in Hénin-Beaumont, many customers in the Café de la Paix received it with the outrage and disappointment Marine Le Pen predicted.

title: Here’s What Some Democratic Voters Say Their Party Should Do
description: Before the election, Julisa Rojas believed that Democrats were by no means perfect, but she thought they could steer the country in a better direction. So, she said she canvassed neighborhoods in Georgia, where she helped register people to vote.

title: Watchdog Agency to Investigate Attempted Cuts to Fair Housing Groups
description: The Department of Housing and Urban Development and the Elon Musk-led Department of Government Efficiency, or DOGE, will now face a federal inquiry into their attempts to slash funds earmarked for the enforcement of fair housing laws.

title: Trump Pauses Dozens of Federal Grants to Princeton
description: The Trump administration moved this week to suspend dozens of federal grants to Princeton University, the fourth Ivy League school that has seen its financial support from Washington reduced or explicitly threatened since March.

title: How the Myanmar Earthquake Shook Skyscrapers in Bangkok
description: More than 600 miles separated the epicenter of Friday’s earthquake in Myanmar from the skyscrapers of Bangkok, which lurched and swayed on the skyline of the vast metropolis. A 33-story high-rise under construction even collapsed. How could the shaking in Bangkok, the Thai capital, be connected to an earthquake so far away?

title: U.N. Accuses Israel of Killing 15 Rescue Workers in Gaza
description: As Israeli forces advanced on the southern Gaza city of Rafah before dawn last Sunday, an ambulance crew set out to evacuate civilians wounded by Israeli shelling. But the ambulance and its crew were hit on the way.

title: Huset Pops Up at the Standard, East Village, With Flavors From Mexico City
description: Maycoll Calderón, the chef and an owner of Huset Cocina de Campo, known for “field cooking” over wood fires for the past 10 years in the Roma Norte section of Mexico City, will be here for a two-month residence in the Standard, East Village. The space has housed other pop-ups. Mr. Calderón, who worked with Jean-Georges Vongerichten earlier in his career, plans to change the dinner menu daily and a New York crowd should feel at home with dishes like tuna tartare, shrimp ceviche, steak taco, roasted sea bass, arroz con pollo and pork Milanese with salad. (Wednesday)

title: Polls Close in Wisconsin’s Key Court Contest
description: Polls were closing on Tuesday evening in Wisconsin, where officials were counting ballots in a nearly $100 million race for control of the State Supreme Court.

title: Fourth U.S. Soldier Is Found Dead in Lithuania
description: The body of a fourth U.S. Army soldier was found on Tuesday in Lithuania, a week after the soldier and three others were reported missing when the armored vehicle they were riding in sank in a bog, the U.S. military said.

title: Trump’s Dismantling of Minority Business Agency Could Hinder Job Growth
description: The Trump administration’s move to gut an agency that aims to support minority-owned businesses has alarmed Democratic lawmakers and nonprofits, who say the action could harm job growth and businesses that rely on the agency’s services.

title: Dr. Oz ‘Disavows’ Support for Transgender Care, Assuaging a Senator’s Concerns
description: Senator Josh Hawley, the Missouri Republican, said on Monday that he had decided to support the nomination of Dr. Mehmet Oz to lead Medicare and Medicaid because Dr. Oz told him that he would no longer support transgender care for minors and was “unequivocally pro-life.”

title: Should Universities Resist Trump’s Tactics?
description: To the Editor:

title: 5 Rikers Detainees Have Already Died This Year as Crisis Worsens
description: In the first three months of the year, five people have died at the Rikers Island jail complex in New York or shortly after being released from city custody, equaling the number of detainees who died in all of 2024.

title: How Would We Build Homes Without Immigrant Labor and Foreign Materials?
description: Take a line-by-line look at the estimated costs of building this four-bedroom home in Phoenix, Ariz., under President Trump’s agenda.

title: Trump’s Tariffs Are Coming, but at a Cost to U.S. Alliances
description: The incoming German chancellor, more convinced than ever that the defense and trade relationship with Washington is crumbling, has made plans to execute on his goal of “independence from the U.S.A.”

title: Florida Sixth District Special Election Results
description: Get live results and maps from the 2025 Florida special election.

title: Wisconsin Supreme Court Election Results
description: Get live results and maps from the 2025 Wisconsin spring elections.

title: Florida First District Special Election Results
description: Get live results and maps from the 2025 Florida special election.

title: Wisconsin Question 1 Election Results
description: Get live results and maps from the 2025 Wisconsin spring elections.

title: Wisconsin Superintendent of Public Instruction Election Results
description: Get live results and maps from the 2025 Wisconsin spring elections.

title: Wisconsin Spring Election Results
description: Get live results and maps from the 2025 Wisconsin spring elections.

title: Florida Special Election Results
description: Get live results and maps from the 2025 Florida special elections.

title: France Moves Closer to Adding a Missing Word to Its Rape Law: Consent
description: Many countries require that consent be given before sex — and have written that into their rape laws. France is not among them.

title: Rubio Orders U.S. Diplomats to Scour Student Visa Applicants’ Social Media
description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio has ordered diplomats overseas to scrutinize the social media content of some applicants for student and other types of visas, in an effort to bar those suspected of criticizing the United States and Israel from entering the country, U.S. officials say.

title: Air Traffic Controller Arrested in Incident at Reagan National Tower
description: An air traffic controller was arrested on Thursday night after an incident in the control tower at Ronald Reagan National Airport, the police said in a statement.

title: Trump Said Auto Emissions Don’t Affect the Environment. That’s Not True.
description: President Trump announced on Monday that he planned to relax limits on pollution from cars, saying that the move wouldn’t “mean a damn bit of difference to the environment.”

title: A Pack of April Fools
description: Happy April Fools’ Day, when you can’t believe anything you read on the internet! Trust that this playlist is a prank-free space, though: We’re just gathering up some of the many fools who have been immortalized in song over the years, by soul singers (Aretha Franklin), blues legends (Bobby “Blue” Bland) and new wavers (Bow Wow Wow). Country and classic rock are in the mix, too — there’s a little something for everyone who’s ever fooled around and fell in love. So hit play, give those dubious corporate social media posts a miss and we’ll try to ride this out together.

title: How to Exfoliate Your Skin
description: If you don’t already have an exfoliation routine, spring — when the weather warms up and skin gets naturally oilier — is a great time to start one. “Exfoliating helps get rid of all the dead cells sitting on the surface of the skin,” says the aesthetician Shani Darden. “Without removing that layer, the skin can look dull, and it’s difficult for other products to penetrate,” plus your pores can become clogged, potentially causing acne. Below are tips for a gentle yet effective approach, from Darden and two other experts: the chef Imogen Kwok, who exfoliates regularly to keep her pores clear after long days in hot kitchens; and the florist and gardener Kitten Grayson, who’s figured out the best scrubs to slough off dirt and sweat.

title: Federal Health Work Force Makes Up Less Than 1% of Agency Spending
description: A few days ago, Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the health secretary, embarked on a media tour to defend his decision to lay off thousands of his department’s workers.

title: Auto Sales Surged in Anticipation of Trump’s Tariffs
description: The auto industry witnessed a different kind of March madness last month as buyers flocked to dealerships to lock in deals before President Trump’s auto tariffs lift prices by thousands of dollars, several carmakers said.

title: Venezuelan Migrants Ask Supreme Court to Block Deportations
description: Lawyers for Venezuelan migrants accused of being members of a violent street gang asked the Supreme Court on Tuesday to continue a temporary block on President Trump’s use of a wartime powers law to send hundreds of people to a prison in El Salvador.

title: Johnson Fails to Kill Bipartisan Measure to Allow Proxy Voting for New Parents
description: Speaker Mike Johnson on Tuesday tried and failed to kill a bipartisan effort to change House rules so that lawmakers would temporarily be allowed to vote remotely after the birth of a child, suffering an embarrassing defeat that paralyzed the chamber and signaled that the proposal could soon be adopted.

title: He Wore a ‘Patriotic’ Hat to a Blue Jays Game. It Got Him Ejected.
description: A fan got kicked out of a baseball stadium last week because the message on his hat appeared to violate a rule against displaying political slogans.

title: A Mysterious Group Says Its Mission Is to Expose Antisemitic Students
description: On March 24, a shadowy group that calls itself Canary Mission posted a new feature on its website, “Uncovering Foreign Nationals,” in response to President Trump’s recent executive order on combating antisemitism.

title: Immigration Officials Detain Former Taliban Ambassador to Spain
description: The Taliban’s former ambassador to Spain was detained by U.S. immigration officials while entering the United States on Saturday, and remained in custody after a federal judge declined to order his release on Monday.

title: What Does the TikTok ‘Cookie Challenge’ Really Prove?
description: When Alissa Torrez, 24, saw TikTok videos of parents doing the viral “cookie challenge” with their toddlers, she immediately wanted to hop on the trend with her 3-year-old son, Oliver.

title: Why Al Gore Is Shifting His Climate Activism Abroad
description: Al Gore, who served as vice president for eight years before becoming a full-time climate activist, knows something about presidential power.

title: More than 230 People Infected With Norovirus on Luxury Cruise Ship
description: More than 230 passengers and crew members have been sickened in an outbreak of norovirus during a 29-day round-trip luxury cruise from England to the Eastern Caribbean, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

title: Voters Cast Ballots in Crucial Wisconsin Supreme Court Race
description: The contest between judges Susan Crawford, a liberal, and Brad Schimel, a conservative whose campaign was backed by the billionaire Elon Musk, will tip the balance of the Wisconsin Supreme Court.

title: Wisconsin Voters Have a Huge Opportunity to Brush Back Trump and Musk
description: Chief Justice John Roberts likes to maintain the dubious pretense that there are no “Obama judges or Trump judges” in the federal judiciary, but nobody is pretending that the vote on Tuesday for a justice on the Wisconsin Supreme Court is anything but blatantly partisan. That single race is “as important as the presidency,” according to Brian Schimming, the chairman of the state Republican Party, and former Gov. Tommy Thompson, a Republican, crowed that Republicans were finally spending as much as Democrats on a judicial race.

title: 5 Takeaways From the Hearing for Trump’s Joint Chiefs Chairman Pick
description: The confirmation hearing on Tuesday for Lt. Gen. Dan Caine, President Trump’s pick to lead the Joint Chiefs of Staff, was strikingly uncontentious.

title: It’s Still April Fools’ Day on Social Media
description: April 1 always seems to begin with social media users reminding everyone that it’s April Fools’ Day.

title: Bongino Tells F.B.I. He Is Not Partisan
description: Dan Bongino, the F.B.I.’s deputy director, who rose to popularity as a conservative podcaster bashing Democrats and praising President Trump, sought to reassure the bureau’s employees that he would not act as a “partisan political figure.”

title: How to Organize Your Pantry
description: [This article was originally published in January 2019.]

title: Here Is the Real Route to Freeing Palestinians
description: The world should remember the name of Odai Al-Rubai. The 22-year-old Palestinian man joined protests in Gaza last week to demand an end to 18 years of Hamas’s violent misrule in the territory. Demonstrators could be heard shouting, “Out, out, Hamas, get out” and “Hamas are terrorists,” while displaying banners saying, “Hamas does not represent us.” In retaliation, Al-Rubai’s family says, he was kidnapped, tortured and murdered by members of Hamas’s Qassam Brigades. Then his body was dumped in front of the family home.

title: This Tree Wants to Be Struck by Lightning
description: When lightning strikes a tree in the tropics, the whole forest explodes.

title: Betty Webb, Who Helped Bletchley Park Code Breakers, Dies at 101
description: Betty Webb, who as a young woman during World War II helped code breakers decipher enemy signals at Britain’s top-secret Bletchley Park, died on Monday.  One of the last surviving members of that group, she was 101.

title: A Lavish Party Inside the Frick’s $220 Million Renovation
description: On a rainy night on the Upper East Side, art world philanthropists, billionaire business moguls and New York socialites scurried under a canopy of umbrellas and into the newly restored Frick.

title: Wednesday Briefing: An Elections Test for Trump
description: Two states held elections yesterday that will provide hints as to how Americans feel about President Trump after 10 weeks back in office.

title: Mike Johnson Inexplicably Doesn’t Want to Help Out New Parents in Congress
description: There will be headlines on Tuesday about Representative Anna Paulina Luna, Republican of Florida, embarrassing House Speaker Mike Johnson, but it’s worth really digging into the substance of the issue at hand.

title: Elon Musk Sued Over Pennsylvania Signature Payments
description: During the height of the 2024 presidential campaign, Elon Musk promised Pennsylvanians a $100 reward for signing a petition in support of free speech and gun ownership rights. The billionaire also offered $47 to anyone who recruited a signatory to the petition — and increased the payment to $100 as Election Day drew near.

title: See Which House Members Rejected Johnson’s Effort Against Proxy Voting
description: Nine Republicans joined Democrats to force a vote to allow members who had new children to vote by proxy.

title: 7-Year-Old Girl Is Killed by Falling Boulder at Lake Tahoe Ski Resort
description: A 7-year-old girl was struck and killed on Saturday by a falling boulder at a Lake Tahoe-area ski resort in Incline Village, Nev., the authorities said.

title: In Adams Case, Some Say It’s Not the Time for Narrow Reading of the Law
description: The federal judge weighing a Justice Department request to drop corruption charges against Mayor Eric Adams of New York has been doing so against an extraordinary backdrop — a series of moves by the Trump administration that have shattered the norms of the American justice system.

title: Musk Again Misleads on Social Security Fraud
description: Elon Musk, the world’s richest man, has continued his campaign to aggressively undercut Social Security, leveling baseless and often misleading attacks on the insurance program.

title: Fired Federal Workers Ask Senators to Stand Up for Them
description: Terminated federal workers have been organizing weekly protests inside the Capitol to share their stories and ask senators to defend them and the work they do on behalf of the American people.

title: Voters Will Offer an Early Assessment of Trump and Musk
description: In Wisconsin and Florida, voters went to the polls today for elections that will offer the best evidence yet of whether President Trump maintains robust support.

title: Kathan Brown, Acclaimed Fine Art Printmaker, Dies at 89
description: Kathan Brown, the founder of the San Francisco-based company Crown Point Press, who helped revive the centuries-old art of intaglio printmaking in the United States, producing limited-edition prints by artists like Elaine de Kooning, Chuck Close and Francesco Clemente, died on March 10 at her home in the Bay Area. She was 89.

title: Trump Expected to Announce Reciprocal Tariffs for Other Countries
description: President Trump is expected to announce new tariffs on goods imported from outside the U.S., which could match the levies that other countries place on products made in America.

title: He Got Clemency From Trump. Now He’s Facing Charges of Injuring a Child.
