description: Investors are breathing a bit easier on Monday, with markets rallying in Asia and Europe on hopes for a reprieve on tech tariffs. The optimism seems to contradict President Trump’s own words.

title: Military Leader Wins Presidential Election in Gabon
description: Gen. Brice Oligui Nguema has won the presidential election in the Central African nation of Gabon, according to provisional results, cementing the military officer’s hold on power after he staged a coup in 2023.

title: When Elected Leaders Pursue Risky Policies, What Can Stop Them?
description: It has been a chaotic few weeks in geopolitics.

title: Trump Describes Russia’s Deadly Strike on Ukrainian City as ‘Horrible’
description: President Trump has said Russia’s deadly missile attack on the Ukrainian city of Sumy was “a mistake,” calling it a “horrible thing” even as members of his administration went further with condemnation that served as a rare critique of Moscow while the White House is pushing for a cease-fire.

title: No Corrections: April 14, 2025
description: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

title: Corrections: April 13, 2025
description: An article on Page 50 this weekend about rebuilding in the Palisades misstates the given name of a former Los Angeles fire chief. She is Kristin Crowley, not Lauren.

title: Can You Uncover the Hidden Titles of a Dozen Recent Best Sellers?
description: Test your knowledge of the best-selling books (so far) in 2025 and build a reading list along the way.

title: Pete Marocco, Who Helped Gut Foreign Aid for Trump, Leaves State Department
description: Pete Marocco, who worked with Elon Musk’s team to oversee the gutting of foreign aid and the dismantling of the main U.S. aid agency, has left the State Department, administration officials said on Monday.

title: Mark Zuckerberg Takes Stand to Defend Meta Against Antitrust Suit
description: Mark Zuckerberg, the chief executive of Meta, took the witness stand on Monday to defend his social media empire in a landmark antitrust trial that could dismantle a company that has transformed how the world connects online.

title: DOGE Cuts Hobble Office That Would Aid NASA and SpaceX Mars Landings
description: An office in an obscure corner of the federal government that NASA has relied on to safely land astronauts on the moon and robotic probes on Mars is facing pressure to cut its tight-knit team of experts by at least 20 percent, according to two people familiar with the mandate.

title: Trump Says He Was Told Russia’s Deadly Strike Was a ‘Mistake’
description: It was not immediately clear what President Trump meant when he said he had been told Russia “made a mistake” with its missile strike on the Ukrainian city of Sumy.

title: Britain Cuts Tariffs on Dozens of Products as Global Trade Tensions Rise
description: The British government ramped up actions to help protect businesses and households from some of the economic tumult created by President Trump’s decision to raise tariffs and upend the norms of global trade.

title: What if Mark Zuckerberg Had Not Bought Instagram and WhatsApp?
description: In 2012, when Facebook’s chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, cut a $1 billion check to buy the photo-sharing app Instagram, most people thought he had lost his marbles.

title: Inside Trump’s Pressure Campaign on Universities
Judge Pauses Trump’s Use of Alien Enemies Act to Deport Venezuelans in Colorado
description: A federal judge temporarily blocked the Trump administration on Monday night from using a powerful wartime statute to deport to El Salvador Venezuelan immigrants in Colorado who have been accused of being violent gang members.

title: The Creator of ‘Cowboy Bebop’ Thinks Reality Is More Dystopian Than Sci-Fi
description: Shinichiro Watanabe’s first anime, “Cowboy Bebop,” was quite an opening act. A story of space bounty hunters trying to scrape by, its genre mash-up of westerns, science fiction and noir, with a jazzy soundtrack, was a critical and commercial success in Japan and beyond. Its American debut on Adult Swim, in 2001, is now considered a milestone in the popularization of anime in the United States.

title: An Electric Chicken Breast Dinner With the Salad Built In
description: Wherever the cook extraordinaire Yewande Komolafe goes, I will absolutely follow — even if it’s to boneless, skinless chicken breasts. Normally I’d prefer literally any other part of the bird (thigh, drumstick, wing, neck, liver, giblets, tail or feet), but I know from experience that Yewande works magic with everything she touches. And that includes the meek and mild chicken breast.

title: Worth Thousands on the Black Market, Lego Kits Are Now a Target of Thieves
description: It’s one Lego kit, a collection of small plastic bricks and related accessories. What could it cost? The answer, it turns out, could be thousands of dollars.

title: Dumbledore and Others Are Cast for ‘Harry Potter’ TV Series
description: Potterheads are one step closer to seeing a television series about the boy wizard come to life, two years after it was announced.

title: One Giant Stunt for Womankind
description: This morning, Jeff Bezos’ private spaceflight startup, Blue Origin, launched six well-known women into space. The company documented the event with a livestream hosted by the sportscaster Charissa Thompson. The celebrities Kris Jenner, Orlando Bloom and Oprah Winfrey watched from the ground. Bezos himself escorted the crew to the capsule. As the rocket blasted into the sky, live audio from inside the ship was broadcast down to Earth. One of the occupants could be heard screaming: “Oh my goddess!”

title: Trump Moves to Put New Tariffs on Computer Chips and Drugs
description: The Trump administration took steps on Monday that appear likely to result in new tariffs on semiconductors and pharmaceutical products, adding to the levies President Trump has put on imports globally.

title: Two Postscripts on a Column
description: “Ain’t I a woman?” Well, no, I’m not.

title: Cuomo Wins Backing of 2 Major Unions That Once Pushed Him to Resign
description: Two influential New York City labor unions that backed Mayor Eric Adams in 2021 switched their support on Monday to former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, reflecting his growing dominance as the race for mayor accelerates.

title: In This French ‘Gypsy,’ Mama’s Got the Stuff. Daughter Too.
description: That “Gypsy” is finally making its debut in France would be noteworthy enough: It took 66 years for one of the most acclaimed works in the musical-theater canon to get there.

title: Fugitive Jeweler Wanted by India Is Arrested in Belgium
description: Mehul Choksi, a wealthy diamond dealer whom India has sought in connection with a fraud case involving one of India’s largest state-run banks, has been arrested in Belgium, his lawyer said on Monday.

title: The Color-Drenched Cult of Le Creuset
description: April Hershberger is not the only collector of Le Creuset cookware who owns so many pieces that she can’t count them. But she may be the only one who built an entire house around one: the deep-red, nine-quart oval Dutch oven she received as a gift for her 2006 wedding.

title: Good Luck Getting Goldman Sachs to Even Say the Word ‘Tariff’
description: Goldman Sachs on Monday revealed its latest financial results and outlook for the future, and in a deft feat of linguistics, its executives managed not to utter the word “tariff” once.

title: Does Love Mean Having to Share Your Location?
description: The Modern Love podcast team is working on an episode about location sharing, and the decisions we make around letting a partner, friend or family member know our whereabouts at all times.

title: L.A. County Expects $2 Billion in Fire Costs, Adding to Budget Woes
description: Los Angeles County is facing a mounting financial crisis, its top manager said on Monday, as expected cuts in federal funding, a record $4 billion settlement for sex-abuse allegations and the destructive wildfires in January threaten Southern California’s economy.

title: Mark Zuckerberg Is Back in the Hot Seat in a Crucial Trial
description: Mark Zuckerberg has appeared before Congress more times than any other tech leader. He will testify again soon — as a witness in a federal antitrust trial. Cecilia Kang, a technology reporter for The New York Times, recalls some of Zuckerberg’s past congressional hearings and explains why the stakes are even higher this time.

title: Former Sheriff’s Deputy Is Sentenced to 3 Years in Killing of Colorado Man
description: A former Colorado sheriff’s deputy was sentenced to three years in prison on Monday in the fatal shooting of a 22-year-old man who called 911 for help as he was experiencing a mental health crisis on a dark mountain road in 2022.

title: Orban Escalates Culture War in Hungary by Mandating Two Genders Only
description: Emboldened by President Trump, Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary on Monday escalated his culture war against what he calls “gender madness,” after his governing party voted to amend the Constitution to mandate that all Hungarians are either male or female.

title: Map: 5.2-Magnitude Earthquake Strikes Southern California
description: View the location of the quake’s epicenter and shake area.

title: Expelled From the Navy: 381 Banned Books
description: To the Editor:

title: An Orange Fish With Arms and Legs, and a Song You Can’t Escape
description: If you have not yet heard the French song about an orange fish named Steve that is currently making the rounds on TikTok, this is your last chance to escape.

title: Cuomo Announces New Housing Plan, With a Hint of ChatGPT
description: For former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, the release of his housing plan on Sunday was to be a major policy moment in his campaign to become mayor of New York City, which is facing its worst housing crunch in more than 50 years.

title: Tariff-Induced Inflation Surge May Be Temporary, Fed Official Says
description: Tariffs of the magnitude that President Trump has enacted are poised to raise inflation in the United States. Whether it will be a temporary surge or one that spirals into a more serious problem is not yet clear, echoing a similar debate that bedeviled officials at the Federal Reserve during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: To Fight Federal Job Cuts, Energy Experts and States Try a New Argument
description: President Trump’s “energy dominance” agenda will be undermined by steep cuts to federal agencies that are said to be planned by the Trump administration, scientists, lawmakers and energy executives warned on Monday.

title: Trump Administration Will Freeze $2 Billion After Harvard Refuses Demands
description: The Trump administration acted quickly on Monday to punish Harvard University after it refused to comply with a list of demands from the federal government that the school said were unlawful.

title: They Followed the Rules. Now Thousands of Migrants Are Told, ‘Leave.’
description: Tens of thousands of immigrants who had been allowed to temporarily live and work in the United States under the Biden administration have received a seemingly unequivocal message in recent days from the Department of Homeland Security.

title: Asparagus Dresses Up for This Springy Dinner Party
description: Some places across the country are still getting frost in the morning; other climes are sunny and warm already. No matter. Let’s move on to springtime in the kitchen.

title: Older People Seeking Care for Cannabis Use at Greater Risk for Dementia, Study Finds
description: Middle-aged and older adults who sought hospital or emergency room care because of cannabis use were almost twice as likely to develop dementia over the next five years, compared with similar people in the general population, a large Canadian study reported on Monday.

title: What to Know About the Deportation of Abrego Garcia to El Salvador
description: President Trump and his deputies are digging in on their refusal to heed a Supreme Court order to “facilitate” the release of a Maryland man who was deported to El Salvador last month despite another court order expressly forbidding him to be sent there.

title: Greene Bought Market Dip Before Trump Paused Tariffs, Profiting From the Rally
description: Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene, Republican of Georgia, disclosed on Monday that she had purchased between tens and hundreds of thousands of dollars’ worth of stock on April 8 and 9, the day before and the day of President Trump’s announcement that he was pausing a sweeping set of global tariffs, a pivot that sent the stock market soaring out of a sizable slump.

title: Arson Attack on Josh Shapiro Raises Fears About Threats to Politicians
description: A charred piano. A singed light fixture dangling by a cord in a fire-scarred room. Plates strewn with ash, not far from a dinner table just cleared from a Passover Seder.

title: Antoni Gaudí Was a Venerated Architect. Now He May Become a Saint.
description: Pope Francis on Monday placed Antoni Gaudí, the Catalan modernist once called “God’s architect” for his work on the Sagrada Familia, Barcelona’s world-famous basilica, on the path to sainthood.

title: The Dollar Keeps Falling as Its ‘Safe Haven’ Status Is Questioned
description: The U.S. dollar’s recent slide against other major currencies has suggested that investors may be starting to shun what has long been the safest haven in global financial markets.

title: Easter Desserts Anyone Can Make
description: Images of rebirth and renewal are everywhere at Easter: hatching chicks, hordes of bunnies and emerging flower buds. Also returning, prompted by the occasion and a crowd to feed, are the seasonal bakers, rested from the holidays and re-energized for spring.

title: 5 Migrants Feared Dead After Boat Capsizes Off Florida Coast
description: Five migrants are feared dead after their boat capsized on the way to Florida from the Bahamas in “a suspected failed smuggling venture,” officials said on Monday.

title: Questions for The Morning
description: On The Morning newsletter, we are fortunate that we can call our colleagues across The New York Times and ask them anything on our mind: What does this policy change mean for taxpayers? How will this treaty affect carbon emissions? Can President Trump do that?

title: Tuesday Briefing: El Salvador Won’t Return Deportee
description: At a White House meeting with President Trump, El Salvador’s president, Nayib Bukele, said yesterday that he would not return a man who was wrongly deported from the U.S. and sent to a notorious prison in El Salvador.

title: 13 Unforgettable Looks at Coachella
description: In the decades since the first Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival took place in Southern California in 1999, its cultural footprint has grown to encompass way more than music. This year’s event, which kicked off over the weekend, reflected that evolution: It was a days-long concert, but also a “White Lotus” reunion, a political rally and, as in years past, a fashion spectacle.

title: Read Harvard’s Response to the Trump Administration
description: Harvard University’s lawyers responded on Monday to the Trump Administration’s letter demanding a series of policy changes, saying the demands were unlawful and that Harvard would not comply.

title: Read the Trump Administration’s Letter to Harvard
description: A letter sent to Harvard on Friday by the Trump administration demanded that the university make a series of policy changes in order to continue to receive federal funding.

title: Eating Frog Legs During Charli XCX’s Coachella Set
description: On Saturday night, as Charli XCX performed the hottest album of 2024 and Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont spoke to young Clairo fans, about 300 people were eating frog legs and beef tongue inside the sweltering V.I.P. Rose Garden of the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival in Indio, Calif.

title: Salvadoran President Says He Won’t Return Wrongly Deported Man
description: During a bilateral meeting in the Oval Office, President Trump also said that he was open to sending American citizens convicted of violent crimes to President Nayib Bukele’s prison in El Salvador.

title: North Dakota Lawmakers Pass Bill Restricting Library Books Deemed Obscene
description: North Dakota lawmakers narrowly passed a bill on Monday that would require most libraries in the state to keep material deemed sexually explicit in areas that are difficult for minors to access. Under the measure, librarians who do not comply could face prosecution.

title: Columbia Activist Arrested by ICE at His Appointment for Citizenship
description: Mohsen Mahdawi, an organizer of pro-Palestinian demonstrations last year at Columbia University, was detained by immigration officials on Monday after arriving for an appointment in Vermont that he thought was a step toward becoming a U.S. citizen, his lawyers said.

title: Brad Holland’s Disruptive Vision
description: Brad Holland, an artist whose conceptual work and iconoclastic ways delighted — and often maddened — generations of art directors, died on March 27.

title: El Salvador Won’t Return Wrongly Deported Man
description: In an Oval Office meeting today with President Trump, El Salvador’s leader said that he would not return a man who was wrongly deported from the U.S. and sent to a notorious prison in El Salvador.

title: As Trump Makes His Case, He Turns to the Oval Office Set Piece
description: It was Monday in Washington, and the tension was palpable.

title: White House to Ask Congress to Claw Back Funding From NPR and PBS
description: The White House is planning to ask Congress to claw back more than $1 billion slated for public broadcasting in the United States, according to two people briefed on the plan, a move that could ultimately eliminate almost all federal support for NPR and PBS.

title: China’s Halt of Critical Minerals Poses Risk for U.S. Military Programs
description: On Air Force fighter jets, magnets made of rare earth minerals that are mined or processed in China are needed to start the engines and provide emergency power.

title: The Moving Goal Posts in Musk’s DOGE Cuts
description: The way Elon Musk tells it, cutting government spending is easy.

title: No Jail Time for Queens Man Convicted of Spying for China
description: For decades, Shujun Wang presented himself as a champion for Chinese dissidents. A military scholar who fled China after the Tiananmen Square massacre, Mr. Wang settled in Queens, where he helped found a group that promoted democracy and criticized Beijing’s authoritarianism.

title: Suspect in Arson at Pennsylvania Governor’s Mansion Had Troubled Past
description: The man charged with attempted murder for setting fire to the Pennsylvania governor’s mansion while Gov. Josh Shapiro and his family slept had a troubled past and a history of mental illness, according to new details on the case that emerged on Monday.

title: Trump Administration Memo Proposes Cutting State Department Funding by Nearly Half
description: The Trump administration could cut nearly 50 percent of the State Department’s funding next fiscal year, according to an internal memo laying out a downsizing plan being given serious consideration by department leaders, said two U.S. officials. The plan was drawn up as the White House pressures agencies to make significant budget cuts.

title: Trump’s Dilemma: A Trade War That Threatens Every Other Negotiation With China
description: President Trump came into office sounding as if he were eager to deal with President Xi Jinping of China on the range of issues dividing the world’s two biggest superpowers.

title: Suspect Arrested in Attacks on New Mexico G.O.P. Office and a Tesla Dealer
description: An Albuquerque man was arrested on Monday in connection with the fire bombings of the Republican Party of New Mexico’s headquarters in March and a Tesla dealership in February, attacks that the federal authorities have designated as “domestic terrorism.”

title: Vance Drops Ohio State’s Championship Trophy During White House Celebration
description: Vice President JD Vance dropped the College Football Playoff’s national championship trophy during an event on the White House South Lawn on Monday, an ill-timed fumble that he laughed about later after it had spread across social media.

title: Harvard’s Decision to Resist Trump Is ‘of Momentous Significance’
description: Harvard University is 140 years older than the United States, has an endowment greater than the G.D.P. of nearly 100 countries and has educated eight American presidents. So if an institution was going to stand up to the Trump administration’s war on academia, Harvard would be at the top of the list.

title: Harvard’s Strength and How Far We’ve Fallen So Quickly
description: The world’s most famous university has done the right thing, and this is major news. It shouldn’t be. But less than three months into the second Trump administration, we are surprised by simple dignity. Capitulation would have garnered smaller headlines.

title: Court Temporarily Blocks Trump’s Shuttering of Migrant Entry Program
description: A federal judge in Boston temporarily blocked the Trump administration on Monday from ending a signature Biden-era program that allowed hundreds of thousands of migrants from four troubled countries to enter the country and work legally.

title: The Vibe Shifts Against the Right
description: Alex Kaschuta’s podcast, “Subversive,” used to be a node in the network between weird right-wing internet subcultures and mainstream conservatism. She hosted men’s rights activists and purveyors of “scientific” racism, neo-reactionary online personalities with handles like “Raw Egg Nationalist” and the Republican Senate candidate Blake Masters. Curtis Yarvin, a court philosopher of the MAGA movement who wants to replace democracy with techno-monarchy, appeared on the show twice. In 2022, Kaschuta spoke at the same National Conservatism conference as Ron DeSantis and Marco Rubio.

title: Corrections: April 15, 2025
description: An article on Saturday about how leaders of the biggest tech companies sought favor with President Trump in an attempt to steer regulation and tariffs to little avail misstated whose administration Gigi Sohn served in. She was a former senior adviser to the Federal Communications Commission under the Obama administration, not the Biden administration.

title: Anatomical Pouch
description: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

title: Missing Rotor Is Recovered From Site of Helicopter Crash in Hudson River
description: When rescue crews reached the passenger compartment of the helicopter that plunged into the Hudson River on Thursday, killing all six of its occupants, the aircraft was missing several critical components, including the rotor and blades that had kept it aloft.

title: Review: In ‘John Proctor Is the Villain,’ It’s the Girls vs. the Men
description: The first word spoken in “John Proctor Is the Villain,” a vital new play in a thrilling production at the Booth Theater on Broadway, is “sex.”

title: Quote of the Day: CAREER SLAM AT LAST
description: “I’m proud of never giving up. I’m proud of how I kept coming back and dusting myself off and not letting the disappointments really get to me.”

title: What Are Rare Earth Metals?
description: For years, the Chinese government has worked to control the export of rare earths, a group of metals used in an array of products, as common as semiconductors and lights. Now, in its trade war with the United States, China is moving to limit the market for these metals even further, which could have disastrous consequences for American manufacturing and military power. So, what exactly are these metals, and why are they so important?

title: Trump’s Trade War With China Could Be Good for India. But Is It Ready?
description: Even when India was staring down the barrel of a 27 percent tariff on most of its exports to the United States, business executives and government officials saw an upside. India’s biggest economic rival, China, and its smaller competitors like Vietnam were facing even worse.

title: A Crisis at a British Steel Mill Has Cast a Shadow Over U.K.-China Relations
description: Britain has sent a parade of senior officials to China this year, part of a calculated charm offensive to thaw out relations with a country that looms large in a world order upended by the United States under President Trump.

title: Airport Was Repeatedly Warned on Bird Strikes Before Deadly South Korea Crash
description: The latest warning came 10 days before the deadliest air crash in South Korea.

title: Vance Fumbles College Football Championship Trophy
description: Vice President JD Vance attempted to lift college football’s biggest prize, but dropped the base. Ohio State Buckeyes players secured the trophy.

title: Haiti’s Gangs Have Evolved. The United States Will Pay the Price.
description: Almost every night, I get phone calls from people in areas of Port-au-Prince, Haiti, under attack by gangs. “Please ask the police to send officers,” one friend said. “Please help me. We’re going to die!” he told me.

title: I’m in Denmark’s Parliament. Here’s Why America Has Us So Stunned.
description: There are moments in history that are difficult to forget, that change the course of events. Danes have experienced several such moments in the past few months, but to me, the most defining one occurred a few weeks ago, when Vice President JD Vance said Denmark is “not being a good ally” to the United States.

title: Tuesday Briefing: El Salvador Will Not Return Deportee
description: At a White House meeting with President Trump, El Salvador’s president, Nayib Bukele, said yesterday that he would not return a man who was wrongly deported from the U.S. and sent to a notorious prison in El Salvador.

title: Word of the Day: invective
description: The word invective has appeared in 64 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Feb. 15 in “The Parking Lot Frisbee Game That Started in 1968 Is Still Going Strong” by David Waldstein. The article is about Ultimate, a sport that’s “essentially football with a Frisbee and no tackling”:

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.

title: Harvey Weinstein, Facing New Charge, Returns to Court in New York
description: Five years after Harvey Weinstein’s New York trial for sex crimes, a watershed moment in the #MeToo era, the disgraced Hollywood mogul is back in a Manhattan courtroom on Tuesday for the start of a new trial.

title: Spring Break
description: If you could go anywhere and do anything for spring break, what would you choose? Would you go to a beach, visit a city or spend time in nature somewhere? Would you pursue a sport or activity? Would you just stay home, sleep late and see your friends?

title: Late Night Weighs In on Trump’s Perfect Physical
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

title: I‘m High Risk for Cancer. What Should I Do?
description: Q: Several people in my family have had cancer, and I’m terrified of getting it, too. How can I reduce my odds?

title: A Novel That Takes On Life’s Greatest Mystery: Our Parents
description: Andrew Porter’s fiction abounds in first-person commentaries, intimate and confiding, by male narrators unafraid to reflect poorly on themselves. Failure is their preoccupation — in career, in marriage — and ambivalence their default mind-set. These are men uncertain about what they want, and prone to an intelligent, rueful lostness. “Once in a while I’d have a feeling that I was missing out on something or being left behind,” says one, “but usually that feeling would pass.”

title: How Long Will the ‘End of the World’ Stay Wild?
description: It was summer in the city that proudly calls itself the “end of the world,” and the tourists were flocking like the penguins they had traveled thousands of miles to see.

title: A Scientist Is Paid to Study Maple Syrup. He’s Also Paid to Promote It.
description: For more than a decade, Navindra Seeram, a biomedical researcher, has praised maple syrup, calling it a “hero ingredient” and “champion food” that could have wide-ranging health benefits.

title: The Centuries-Long Struggle to Make English Words Behave
description: A century ago, one of the richest men in the world decided to wade into the public sphere by throwing his weight behind a series of cuts that would reach into every corner of American life. The president of the day, sensing early support for these reforms and not wishing to be left behind, jumped on board with impulsive zeal, demanding that all federal offices implement the cutbacks with immediate effect.

title: Build Homes on Federal Land
description: The big industry in this pretty city in southwestern Utah is building and selling homes, and business is so good that St. George is running out of land.

title: How an Anime Master Perfects the Cool Guy Action Hero
description: When it comes to creators who have defined contemporary anime, Shinichiro Watanabe is no less than a television auteur. His anime series, which include the renowned “Cowboy Bebop” and “Samurai Champloo,” are known for thrilling fight scenes, propulsive musical scores and fun, unpredictable characters.

title: Who Are the Venezuelan Deportees Sent to El Salvador?
description: Who are the 238 Venezuelans deported by the Trump administration without due process to El Salvador’s maximum-security Terrorism Confinement Center? Julie Turkewitz, a bureau chief for The New York Times, explains what her team’s investigation reveals about the deportees, their criminal records and how they were selected for deportation.

title: ‘Alien Enemies’ or Innocent Men? Inside Trump’s Rushed Effort to Deport 238 Migrants
description: Follow live updates on the Trump administration here.

title: This Global Warming Book Is a Token From Another World
description: The political commentator Malcolm Harris would love to offer the world a road map. “I refuse to believe,” he declares in “What’s Left,” his impassioned guide to our current impasses over global warming, “that we have no alternative to the universal human project’s erosion into parochial barbarisms and petty domination.” We need, Harris writes, a “reasonable alternative to boiling ourselves alive.”

title: Inside Trump’s Plan to Halt Hundreds of Regulations
description: At the Department of Health and Human Services, Trump administration officials want to reverse a regulation that has required nursing homes to have more medical staff on duty.

title: The Harp Needs More Modern Music. That’s Easier Said Than Done.
description: I once asked a colleague who runs a concert series what came to mind when he thought of harp music. “A nothingburger,” he replied. I laughed, not because I was shocked but because I agreed.

title: The Techno-Utopians Who Want to Colonize the Sea
description: Forty-six hours before Rüdiger Koch officially seized the Guinness World Record for the longest time spent living in an underwater fixed habitat, I took a 15-minute motorboat ride from Linton Bay Marina, in north-central Panama, to visit him. It was a warm afternoon in January, and Koch was approaching a full 120 days spent working, eating, sleeping, drinking and smoking cigars in a room 36 feet below the surface of the Caribbean.

title: Trump’s Tariffs Hurt the Very Thing That Drives the Economy
description: The Trump administration talks a lot about stoking American business investment, an admirable and important goal. In March on social media, President Trump said that his first two months back in office had seen more private investment “spoken for, and/or committed to” than the prior four years. The Washington Post’s Glenn Kessler noted that the president’s claim compared apples (focusing on money spent to develop new factories) with oranges (vague corporate announcements about future investment).

title: 30 Years Later, a New Look at the Oklahoma City Bombing
description: David Glover holds up what looks like a pair of gray bricks. They were once part of the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building in Oklahoma City, which was bombed by Timothy McVeigh on April 19, 1995, killing 168 people. It remains the deadliest domestic terror attack in U.S. history.

title: Why Should I Change My Name? He’s the Problem.
description: Recently, as I was getting into a car, the driver clocked my name and asked, “Like Musk?” I sighed and answered as I have now dozens of times: Yes, just like the stiff-arm salute guy.

title: Relaxation and Luxury Meet in a Designer’s Home Studio
description: Alfredo Paredes has spent his career refining a luxurious-yet-relaxed take on quintessentially American interior design. For 33 years, he worked at Ralph Lauren, where he was named a chief creative officer and tasked with ensuring that the esteemed brand’s stores, restaurants, events and home furnishings collection were as captivating as they were comfortable.

title: A Stunning, Stress-Free Easter Dish Everyone Will Love
description: Some holiday traditions are meant to evolve.

title: What Life Is Like for Sean Combs, Inmate 37452-054
description: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll find out about the latest court appearance by the music mogul Sean Combs, who is known as Puff Daddy and Diddy — and about conditions in the jail unit where he has lived for seven months. We’ll also get details on why a relatively small number of restaurants have applied for permits for outdoor dining structures under new city regulations.

title: What Is Your Favorite Poem?
description: Have you ever read a poem that moved you to tears? That delighted or inspired you? That made you see the world in a new way? That made you understand yourself or someone else better? That made you feel seen or loved?

title: Housewares Retailers Brace for Tariffs
description: Walk into Pearl River Mart in Soho and the store is a sensory marvel of imported goods that could fill a home — colorful cups and bowls, teapots, paper lanterns, vases and ceramic figurines. There’s the paper lantern a shopper might impulsively buy on a Sunday afternoon, or the wok and spatula waiting to stock a new apartment. About 65 percent of the merchandise comes from China.

title: Tom Friedman Thinks We’re Getting China Dangerously Wrong
description: The Times Opinion columnist discusses what he thinks Trump — and American policymakers — misunderstand about China in the escalating trade war.

title: Debbie Millman and Roxane Gay on Pink Elephants and Gardening
description: Enter the L.A. Home They Have Turned Into a Gallery

title: Van Gogh’s Last Painting Poses a Problem for an Idyllic French Village
description: Auvers-sur-Oise, a village near Paris famed as an artist’s paradise, is also where Vincent Van Gogh spent his final days and it has long drawn tourists to walk in the tortured painter’s last footsteps. But ever since art experts identified his final work before he took his life, there has been strife in the town.

title: Inside Trump’s Plan to Deregulate America
description: The Trump administration wants to get rid of rules that affect health, food, workplace safety, transportation and more. Coral Davenport, a reporter covering energy and environmental policy, explains how the Trump administration plans a set of novel legal strategies to repeal or stop enforcing regulations that have historically taken years to undo, according to people familiar with the plans.

title: Why Trump Could Lose His Trade War With China
description: This is an edited transcript of an episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.” You can listen to the conversation by following or subscribing to the show on the NYT Audio App, Apple, Spotify, Amazon Music, YouTube, iHeartRadio or wherever you get your podcasts.

title: Wordle Review No. 1,397
description: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

title: Harvard vs. Trump, and Your (Shrinking) Chance of Being Audited
description: On Today’s Episode:

title: Connections Companion No. 675
description: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

title: Trapped Abroad: The Man at the Center of a Constitutional Standoff
description: When President Trump met with El Salvador’s president, Nayib Bukele, at the White House, the fate of one man was hanging in the balance.

title: Wild Turkey Struts in New York
description: Astoria, a wild turkey, seen living free on Roosevelt Island in New York.

title: Astoria the Celebrity Turkey Returns to Ritzy Midtown Manhattan
description: On Roosevelt Island, she had her home, her friends and the security of a small community where everyone knew her. Cars slowed down for her. Residents helped her cross the road.

title: JD Vance Sees ‘Good Chance’ of Trade Deal With Britain
description: Vice President JD Vance predicted that President Trump would make a trade deal with Britain, a country “he really loves,” a comforting sign for a British government that was stung to be placed under a 10 percent tariff by Mr. Trump.

title: Changing the Rules
description: The government makes — and unwinds — rules slowly.

title: Trump’s Give-and-Take Tariff Strategy
description: Global markets have gone from “yippy” to feeling calmer, with stocks in Asia and Europe mostly higher this morning and the dollar showing signs of life.

title: Director of Field Hospital in Southern Gaza Says Israeli Strike Killed a Guard
description: An Israeli strike killed a security guard and wounded 10 patients at a field hospital in southern Gaza on Tuesday, according to the director of the medical facility.

title: Weekly Student News Quiz: Tariffs, Roof Collapse, 'A Minecraft Movie'
description: Have you been paying attention to current events recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.

title: Elegantly Swaddled in Neutral Shades
description: Cocooned in fuzzy, tonal attire, Simonne Dom exuded a cozy sophistication as we crossed paths in the Marylebone section of London on a Saturday in March. Her soft garments in shades of beige embodied the two-word description she gave for her style: “casual chic.”

title: Onstage and Off, Whitney White Is Everywhere This Spring
description: This spring, Whitney White directed the ensemble drama “Liberation” Off Broadway, then the two-hander “The Last Five Years” on Broadway. Just days after that musical opened, she stood in an upstairs room at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, rehearsing “Macbeth in Stride,” her adaptation of the Shakespeare tragedy, which begins performances on Tuesday.

title: Intense Sandstorm in Iraq Grounds Flights and Fills Emergency Rooms
description: A severe sandstorm swept central and southern Iraq, reducing visibility, halting flights and causing respiratory problems for thousands, according to officials. Experts say such storms are worsening as drought and desertification increase, driven by climate change.

title: Sandstorm Turns Iraq’s Skies Orange and Sends Thousands to Hospitals
description: A severe sandstorm has swept across central and southern Iraq over the last two days, turning the sky a strange orange, reducing visibility in some places to less than a half mile and sending several thousand people to emergency rooms with respiratory problems.

title: Stocks Fluctuate as Investors Assess Tariff Scenarios
description: Stocks maintained a degree of calm on Tuesday, even as the Trump administration’s chaotic tariff rollout continued to sow more uncertainty.

title: Attackers Target Prisons in France, Burning Vehicles and Firing Shots
description: Attackers targeted a prison near the French port city of Toulon overnight Monday to Tuesday, burning vehicles and firing shots at its walls, French authorities and a union said on Tuesday, adding that this was part of a series of attacks on the country’s prisons.

title: Trump’s Tariff Threat for Imported Medicines Poses Political Risks
description: President Trump’s decision to move a step closer to imposing tariffs on imported medicines poses considerable political risk, because Americans could face higher prices and more shortages of critical drugs.

title: W.N.B.A. Draft Picks Dress to Impress
description: The W.N.B.A. draft began not just with odds-making, taking bets on what player would go at what pick to what team (well, except for Paige Bueckers, who was a lock as the No. 1 pick for Dallas), but with an announcement.

title: Fedora Returns to the West Village for an Encore. Again.
description: The Village, West and Greenwich, are neighborhoods that hang onto historic restaurants. They may close, but then someone rides to the rescue. Dante, Waverly Inn, Minetta Tavern, Figaro and, with an encore, Fedora. Gabriel Stulman revived it for 10 years, until 2020. Now the partners from St. Jardim nearby, Andrew Dete and Christa Alexander, with Basile Al Mileik, St. Jardim’s wine director, have stepped in. They’ve refreshed the cozy interior, and are reopening it with a European-inspired menu by Monty Forrest from Le Rock, who’s offering asparagus tempura, pierogi with alliums and peas, tilefish in bourride, and black bass Provençal. The wine list leans French. The original sign still tips its hat to Fedora Dorato, the owner from 1952 until 2010.

title: Affordable Dishes That Taste Like a Billion Bucks
description: Hi, all! Genevieve here, stepping in for Emily.

title: After an Earthquake, These Elephants Knew Exactly Whom to Follow: Mom
description: The 5.2 magnitude earthquake that shook Southern California on Monday may have provoked a collective shrug from humans in the region, but a few elephants north of San Diego took the tremor very seriously.

title: Santa Lives in Rovaniemi, Finland. Some of His Neighbors Are Not Thrilled.
description: After dinner at the Bull Bar and Grill in the small Finnish city of Rovaniemi, Mariel Tähtivaara, a law student, popped into a supermarket to grab some dessert.

title: Why a Tariff-Inflated $2,000 iPhone Is Nothing to Fear
description: On Friday, amid a tariff-induced frenzy that drove hordes of consumers to panic-buy iPhones, President Trump announced a tariff exemption on electronics like smartphones and computers. For a moment, widespread anxiety about a potential $2,000 iPhone dissipated.

title: Elsa Honig Fine, 94, Dies; Historian Promoted Black and Female Artists
description: Elsa Honig Fine, an art historian who founded a feminist art journal and published influential textbooks on Black and female artists in an era when scholarship in those areas was scarce, died on April 7 at her home in Manhattan. She was 94.

title: Trump Threatens Harvard’s Tax Status, Escalating Billion-Dollar Pressure Campaign
description: President Trump threatened Harvard University’s tax-exempt status on Tuesday after the school rebuffed his administration’s demands for a series of policy changes, a dramatic escalation in the feud between the president and the nation’s richest and oldest university.

title: France Says It Will Expel 12 Algerian Officials as Tensions Rise
description: Tensions between France and Algeria, never far from the surface, flared as the two countries engaged in tit-for-tat expulsions of officials working at each of their embassies and consulates.

title: Tracking Tropical Cyclone Errol
description: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Errol.

title: Lincoln Center Summer Festival to Bring Back Some Classical Music
description: Lincoln Center’s summer festival will highlight the city’s diverse cultural traditions, the center announced on Tuesday, including performances by an experimental collective; a celebration of Brazilian culture; and the staging of a Sanskrit epic.

title: ‘We Don’t Have a Day or Night of Calm’
description: A gigantic, roiling cloud of black smoke swirled up from a parking lot of burning cars, as residents milled about on a sidewalk in distress, and police and fire vehicles careened past. Then the scene became more chaotic.

title: In Showdowns With the Courts, Trump Is Increasingly Combative
description: The Trump administration’s compliance with court orders started with foot-dragging, moved to semantic gymnastics and has now arrived at the cusp of outright defiance.

title: Senators Investigate Private Equity Role in Soaring Fire-Truck Costs
description: As fire departments around the country report soaring prices and waiting times for new fire engines, two United States Senators are investigating the effect on public safety and the role that private equity investment has played in disrupting the firefighting equipment industry.

title: ‘#1 Happy Family USA’ Is a Bittersweet Coming-of-Age Sitcom
description: A Muslim family in New Jersey facing bigotry after Sept. 11 doesn’t sound like a particularly fruitful sitcom premise. But Ramy Youssef has managed to make the subject matter grimly hilarious in his new animated series, “#1 Happy Family USA,” premiering Thursday on Amazon Prime Video.

title: In ‘Towards Zero,’ Agatha Christie Gets Steamy
description: In the second episode of the BBC’s latest Agatha Christie adaptation, a bride walks into the hall of a large country house and finds her husband standing on the elegant curved staircase, with his head buried beneath the silk evening gown his ex-wife is wearing.

title: Two Defiant Presidents vs. a Deported Immigrant
description: To the Editor:

title: Marvin Levy, Oscar-Winning Publicist to Spielberg, Dies at 96
description: Reporters trying to get interviews with Steven Spielberg would sometimes grouse that his publicist’s job amounted to speaking a single word: “No.”

title: What History Can Teach Us About Breaking Up Giant Companies
description: The last time the courts seriously weighed the wisdom of breaking up a giant technology company was a quarter-century ago, after Microsoft was found to have illegally stifled competition in personal computer software.

title: Some Online Scam Victims Can Now Seek Tax Relief on Firmer Ground
description: Victims of sophisticated online scams are often dealt a double whammy. Not only is their money forever gone, but these stolen sums often generate giant tax bills when the funds are emptied from taxable retirement accounts.

title: At Trial, Zuckerberg Defends Buying Instagram and WhatsApp
description: In his second day on the stand in a landmark antitrust trial, Mark Zuckerberg, the chief executive of Meta, on Tuesday defended the social media company’s 2012 acquisition of Instagram, describing the transaction as business as usual for a tech company.

title: Jordan Says It Foiled a Plot Against the Kingdom
description: The Jordanian security services said Tuesday that they had arrested 16 people they accused of plotting threats to national security involving weapons, explosives and plans to manufacture drones and train combatants, both domestically and abroad.

title: More Than 20,000 I.R.S. Employees Offer to Resign
description: About 22,000 employees at the Internal Revenue Service have signed up for the Trump administration’s latest resignation offer, according to four people familiar with the matter, an exodus that could weaken the agency’s ability to collect taxes.

title: American Airlines Will Offer Free Wi-Fi on Most Flights Next Year
description: Beginning next year, if you catch an American Airlines flight, you won’t have to pay to watch shows or movies, keep up with the latest news or endlessly scroll your social media feeds to pass the time.

title: Fans of ‘The Great Moose Migration’ Prep for a Weekslong Binge Watch
description: The popular annual livestream that follows the migration of Sweden’s moose population began on Tuesday.

title: The ‘Great Moose Migration’ Livestream Captivates Sweden
description: Who would spend hours a day watching moose trudge through northern Sweden on their annual spring migration? Lots of people, it turns out.

title: Columbia Vows to Reject Any Trump Deal That Erodes Its Independence
description: Columbia University, which has faced criticism for not striking a more defiant stand against efforts by the Trump administration to set its agenda, showed signs late Monday of adopting a tougher tone. In a note sent to the campus, the acting president pledged that the school would not allow the federal government to “require us to relinquish our independence and autonomy.”

title: A Tax Day Jam Session
description: Lindsay is still out, which means you’ve got me (an editor who focuses on pop culture) on a day where you may need a bit of good fortune: Tax Day.

title: House Tour | Francesco Vezzoli
description: The artist’s apartment and studio in Milan display his large collection of Memphis Group furniture, as well as midcentury vases by the designer and sculptor Giovanni Gariboldi.

title: An Artist’s Surreal Milan Home, With a Life-Size Sculpture of Sophia Loren
description: When the Italian artist Francesco Vezzoli was in his early 20s, he lived in the back room of an office in an 18th-century building in the middle of Milan. It belonged to the lighting brand Flos, and Piero Gandini, then the company’s owner, “was a patron of mine in the 15th-century sense, in that he was literally paying for my bed,” the artist says. Nearly 20 years later, when he came across an apartment for rent in the same building, he immediately took it. “It was the greatest gift. I already knew how the space worked,” says Vezzoli, now 53. “The fewer things you have to worry about, the more you can dedicate to your [art].” He now also uses a unit on the floor below as his studio and gallery. “If the same slice became free on another floor,” he says. “I’d get it just for the sake of it.”

title: This Therapist Helped Clients Feel Better. It Was A.I.
description: The quest to create an A.I. therapist has not been without setbacks or, as researchers at Dartmouth thoughtfully describe them, “dramatic failures.”

title: Autopsies of Gaza Medics Killed by Israeli Troops Show Some Were Shot in the Head
description: The paramedics and rescue workers killed in an Israeli shooting in Gaza last month died mainly from gunshots to the head or chest, while others had shrapnel injuries or other wounds, according to autopsy reports obtained by The New York Times.

title: How Trump Might Unwittingly Cut Emissions From Online Shopping
description: Fast-fashion giants like Shein and Temu have been doing booming business in the United States in recent years, in part because of a tariff exemption that’s helped to keep prices low on packages shipped from China.

title: Adams Is Letting ICE Into Rikers. The City Council Is Suing to Stop Him.
description: The City Council sued Mayor Eric Adams on Tuesday in an attempt to block an executive order that permitted the Trump administration to open offices at the Rikers Island jail complex as part of its immigration crackdown.

title: Palin Libel Retrial Against The New York Times Begins
description: A retrial of the yearslong defamation case brought by Sarah Palin against The New York Times got underway before a Manhattan jury on Tuesday.

title: As the Border Wars Recede, a Park on the Rio Grande Reopens to the Public
description: On Monday morning, as temperatures rose toward sweltering, Dora Flores warily approached the entrance of a modest park in the border city of Eagle Pass, Texas, wanting to see for herself whether the armed guards and concertina wire that had kept residents out for over a year had actually disappeared.

title: LeBron James, ASAP Rocky and Everything You Need to Know About the 2025 Met Gala
description: By now, you probably know the first Monday in May is not just any old Monday: It’s the Metropolitan Museum of Art Costume Institute benefit, a.k.a. the Oscars of the East Coast or the party of the year. We think of it as the Fashion X Games or the All-Star Game of Entrances.

title: It Took a Century to Find This Colossal Squid
description: In March, Kat Bolstad returned from an Antarctic expedition where she had used a new camera system specially built to search for the elusive colossal squid.

title: Sperm Donors in the Netherlands Fathered More Than 25 Children Each, New Data Reveals
description: Somewhere in the Netherlands, there are men who have unknowingly fathered dozens of children through sperm donation. At least one man has sired up to 125 children.

title: Our 17 Most Lemony Recipes
description: Lemon is a wonder. It can transform a rich, creamy dish like pudding or cheesy pasta into something light and nuanced. And sure, you can add acid to a dish in many ways — vinegar, yogurt, fermented vegetables — but none offers as perfect a balance of adaptability and bright freshness as lemon. Whether you’ve got a glut of lemons or you’re just looking to make a kitchen staple shine in new ways, these lemon recipes won’t disappoint.

title: Richard L. Armitage, 79, Dies; State Department Official in a Turbulent Era
description: Richard L. Armitage, who served as the No. 2 official at the State Department from 2001 to 2005, during the turbulent era of the 9/11 attacks and the start of America’s retaliatory wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, died on Sunday. He was 79.

title: U.S. Cites Mideast Peace Process to Justify Move to Deport Student
description: The Trump administration is seeking to deport a Columbia student because his activities could “potentially undermine” the Middle East peace process, according to a memo from Secretary of State Marco Rubio that was reviewed by The New York Times.

title: It’s a Mistake to Think the Biggest Problem With Iran Is Nuclear Weapons
description: President Trump said on Monday that he will “solve the Iran problem” and that “it’s almost an easy one.”

title: 19 Big Cats Rescued in Spain as Police Raid Animal Smuggling Ring
description: The Spanish police say they rescued 19 exotic felines from a home on the island of Majorca that were bound for sale on the growing illegal world market for big cats, and they arrested the Russian couple who owned them.

title: This Isn’t the First Time Trump Has Mistakenly Deported Someone
description: Follow live updates on the Trump administration here.

title: Judge Blocks Trump From Retaliating Against Another Top Law Firm
description: A federal judge on Tuesday blocked President Trump from punishing the law firm Susman Godfrey, calling the retribution campaign he has waged from the White House against the nation’s top firms “a shocking abuse of power.”

title: Wednesday Briefing: A Trump-Harvard Showdown
description: After freezing $2.2 billion in funding to Harvard University, President Trump turned up the pressure yesterday and threatened to revoke its tax-exempt status.

title: A.I. Action Figures Flood Social Media (Accessories Included)
description: This week, the actress Brooke Shields posted an image of an action-figure version of herself that came with a needlepoint kit and a pet terrier. Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene, Republican of Georgia, imagined her own figurine accompanied by a gavel and a Bible.

title: Trump Turned Up the Pressure on Harvard
description: President Trump suggested today that Harvard University could be stripped of its tax-exempt status after the school refused to bow to the government’s demands. Federal law prohibits the president from directing the I.R.S. to investigate specific organizations, but Trump’s threat was nevertheless a dramatic escalation in the feud between the government and the nation’s richest and oldest university.

title: ‘Nothing Has Been Done’: Judge Rebukes U.S. Effort to Return Wrongly Deported Man
description: Follow live updates on the Trump administration here.

title: C.I.A. Director’s Messages in Leaked Chat Were Deleted, Agency Says
description: All of the messages from a leaked group chat have been deleted from the phone of John Ratcliffe, the C.I.A. director, the agency said in a court filing.

title: Inside the Changing White House Briefing Room
description: The Trump administration has given more time to “new media” and outlets that are more supportive of the president’s policies.

title: Autism Rate Continues to Rise Among Children, C.D.C. Reports
description: The percentage of American children estimated to have autism spectrum disorder increased in 2022, continuing a long-running trend, according to data released on Tuesday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

title: How a Nifty Government Tool Knows About Earthquakes Before You Feel Them
description: Millions of people across Southern California learned about a 5.2-magnitude earthquake that hit San Diego County on Monday not from their windows rattling or their picture frames clattering, but from a noisy alert on their mobile phones seconds before the shaking started.

title: I Have Never Been More Afraid for My Country’s Future
description: So much crazy happens with the Trump administration every day that some downright weird but incredibly telling stuff gets lost in the noise. A recent example was the scene on April 8 at the White House where, in the middle of his raging trade war, our president decided it was the perfect time to sign an executive order to bolster coal mining.

title: D.C. Mayor Prepares City for Cuts After Congress Goes on Break
description: The mayor of Washington, D.C., ordered citywide spending and hiring freezes on Tuesday and raised the possibility of furloughs after the U.S. House of Representatives left for recess with the District still facing a potential billion-dollar budget cut.

title: Top Pentagon Advisers Placed on Leave in Leak Investigation
description: Two top advisers to Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth were escorted from the Pentagon on Tuesday and a third official followed on Wednesday as part of an investigation into an unauthorized disclosure of sensitive information, U.S. defense officials said.

title: Wife of Gene Hackman Asked About Flulike Symptoms Before Their Deaths
description: Days before she and her husband, the actor Gene Hackman, died at their home, Betsy Arakawa repeatedly searched online about flu- and Covid-like symptoms, according to records released on Tuesday by New Mexico authorities.

title: Grassley Draws Jeers From Constituents at Raucous Town Hall
description: Angry constituents on Tuesday confronted Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, about President Trump’s refusal to bring back a Salvadoran immigrant mistakenly sent to a prison in El Salvador.

title: Trump Seeks to Lower Drug Prices Through Medicare and Some Imports
description: Follow live updates on the Trump administration here.

title: State Dept. Expands Plans for Closing Embassies and Consulates
description: The Trump administration is considering plans to close 10 embassies and 17 consulates and reduce or consolidate the staff of several other foreign missions, according to an internal State Department memo viewed by The New York Times.

title: White House Ends a Regular Reporting Slot for Independent Newswires
description: The Trump administration said Tuesday that it would no longer reserve a regular slot in the presidential press pool for three independent newswires that have participated for decades, including The Associated Press.

title: A.C.L.U. Sues Defense Department Schools Over Book Bans
description: The American Civil Liberties Union sued the Department of Defense’s education agency on Tuesday, arguing that the removal of books in response to Trump administration orders infringed on the First Amendment rights of students.

title: Biden Condemns Trump’s Cuts to Social Security Administration
description: In his first expansive public comments since leaving the White House, former President Joseph R. Biden Jr. spoke out against the Trump administration’s cuts to the Social Security Administration.

title: Nvidia Says U.S. Will Restrict Sales of More of Its A.I. Chips to China
description: Nvidia said on Tuesday that the U.S. government had blocked the sale of some of its artificial intelligence chips to China without a license and would begin requiring a license for future sales.

title: New York Leaders Agree to Ease Evidence Requirements for Prosecutors
description: After weeks of infighting and political grandstanding, Democratic leaders in New York said on Tuesday that they had reached agreement on a contentious issue holding up this year’s state budget negotiations: criminal discovery.

title: Trump Gives Conflicting Signals and Mixed Messages on Iran Nuclear Talks
description: Just a few weeks ago, President Trump’s national security adviser, Michael Waltz, a longtime hawk on Iran, cast the administration’s goal in negotiations over Tehran’s nuclear program in crystal clear terms.

title: 4 Injured in Dallas School Shooting, Authorities Say
description: Three students were wounded in a shooting on Tuesday at a Dallas high school where, almost exactly a year ago, a student was shot in the leg by a classmate, the authorities said.

title: What Trump’s Meeting With Bukele Means
description: President Nayib Bukele of El Salvador has found a spot on the global stage by opening the doors of his prison system to President Trump. Zolan Kanno-Youngs, a White House correspondent for The New York Times, explains how Bukele, a self-proclaimed dictator, has gone from a pariah to a partner of Trump.

title: Wink Martindale, Popular and Durable Game Show Host, Dies at 91
description: Wink Martindale, a radio personality who became a television star as a dapper and affable host of game shows like “Gambit” and “Tic-Tac-Dough” in the 1970s and ’80s and “Debt” in the ’90s, died on Tuesday in Rancho Mirage, Calif. He was 91.

title: What to Know as Trump Freezes Federal Funds for Harvard and Other Universities
description: The showdown between the Trump administration and institutions of higher learning intensified on Tuesday, when President Trump threatened Harvard University’s tax-exempt status after the school refused to accept his administration’s demands on hiring, admissions and curriculum.

title: Biden Says Trump Is ‘Breaking Things,’ Including the Safety Net
description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. forcefully defended Social Security in a speech to disability advocates in Chicago on Tuesday, condemning the Trump administration for “taking a hatchet” to the Social Security Administration.

title: A Top Democratic Official Plots to Take Down Party Incumbents
description: Less than three months after the young political activist David Hogg was elected as a vice chair of the Democratic National Committee, he is undertaking a new project that is sure to rankle some fellow Democrats: spending millions of dollars to oust Democratic members of Congress in primary elections next year.

title: Corrections: April 16, 2025
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about President Nayib Bukele of El Salvador saying he would not return a Maryland man who was wrongly deported from the United States and sent to a notorious Salvadoran prison misidentified the location of MS-13’s operations. The gang is active in Central America and the United States, not South America.

title: Hong Kong Suspends Packages to the U.S., Wading Into the Trade War
description: Stepping into the trade war, Hong Kong said on Wednesday that its postal service will no longer send packages to the United States.

title: Why Harvard Decided to Fight Trump
description: Follow live updates on the Trump administration here.

title: Damage, So to Speak
description: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

title: China Girds for Economic Stress of Trump’s Tariffs
description: President Trump’s tariffs have been good for China’s economic growth. At least they were over the first three months of the year, as the country’s factories raced to ship exports ahead of the trade restrictions.

title: 2 Protesters at Marjorie Taylor Greene Town Hall Are Subdued With Stun Guns
description: A town hall for Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene of Georgia outside of Atlanta on Tuesday quickly deteriorated into chaos, as police officers forcibly removed several protesters.

title: U.S. Military Says 2 Killed in Vehicle Accident Near Mexico Border
description: Two U.S. service members involved in operations near the border with Mexico were killed in a vehicle accident on Tuesday morning, and another was seriously injured, the military said.

title: Quote of the Day: Trump Flirts With Defying Court Orders
description: “It is alarming that we are even having to ask whether the government is failing to comply with court orders.”

title: Trump Has Threatened Much Worse, but the 10% Tariffs Will Still Sting
description: Follow live updates on the Trump administration here.

title: Taiwan’s Chip Companies Are Caught in the U.S.-China Tariff War
description: Even as the United States and China push their economies further apart with escalating tariffs, they share an inescapable challenge. Both depend on Taiwan for semiconductors.

title: Schumer Moves to Block Trump Picks for Two Key Prosecutor Positions
description: Democrats have so far failed to derail any of President Trump’s nominees, lacking the numbers in the Senate to block them. But they are about to test their ability to use an arcane Senate tradition to stop Mr. Trump from installing one lesser-known but critical category of nominee: federal prosecutors.

title: Trump Joins Japan Trade Talks, Says ‘Big Progress’ Made
description: This month in the White House’s Rose Garden, as he held up a placard showing the global wave of tariffs he wanted to impose, President Trump paused to fondly recall a fallen friend.

title: A U.S.-China Trade War With Students and Tourists as Potential Pawns
description: China has warned its people to think twice before visiting the United States, citing trade tensions. It also told its students to be careful about studying there and accused two American universities of hacking. And it has vowed to cut down on the number of Hollywood films that can be shown in China.

title: Wednesday Briefing: A Trump-Harvard Showdown
description: After freezing $2.2 billion in funding to Harvard University, President Trump turned up the pressure yesterday and threatened to revoke its tax-exempt status.

title: I Trained at an Amazon Center in Hangzhou. You’d Be Surprised What They Think of Trump.
description: In China, one of many nicknames for President Trump is Chuan Jianguo. It literally translates as “Trump the Nation Builder.” My best translation is “Comrade Trump.” The joke is that Mr. Trump is a patriotic son of China who is diligently advancing Chinese interests by causing chaos in the United States.

title: Stocks Fall as Powell Sees Tariff Challenges and Tech Pulls Back
description: Stocks slumped on Wednesday as investors faced new evidence of how the global trade war will hurt some of the world’s biggest technology companies, and heard from the Federal Reserve about the challenge it faces if prices rise while growth slows.

title: Word of the Day: soporific
description: The word soporific has appeared in 14 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on March 21 in “This Hong Kong Art Show Aims to Put You to Sleep” by Christy Choi:

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.

title: Hunting the Wild Mushrooms of New York City
description: New York City can be a place of almost incomprehensible abundance. Its eight million residents speak 700 languages. It has 29,000 restaurants and bars.

title: How a Reporter Stopped Worrying and Learned to Love Steak Fries
description: At first, I had nothing more than a rant in mind. It was January, and I had been to two restaurants in the span of a single week that had served me steak fries, first alongside some lamb chops, the second time next to a burger. On both occasions I had felt the instant pang of disappointment, followed by an unhappy sort of wonderment.

title: Fur Coat
description: Decades of coordinated campaigning, involving protests and even personal attacks outside stores and fashion shows, led by organizations like PETA, created a stigma around wearing real fur in recent years. But now vintage pieces are popping up all over, a Times article reports.

title: Congresswoman and Allies Endorse 3 Mayoral Candidates to Stop Cuomo
description: Representative Nydia Velázquez and six other Democrats from Brooklyn endorsed a slate of three candidates in the New York City mayor’s race on Wednesday, hoping to stop former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s momentum.

title: Late Night Revels in Harvard’s Rejection of Trump’s Demand
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

title: As Fentanyl Deaths Slow, Meth Comes for Maine
description: Something worrisome was happening at Spurwink, a mental health clinic in Portland, Maine. Many patients being treated for opioid addiction had gone missing for days, even weeks, skipping prescription refills and therapy appointments.

title: Tucson, Ariz.: Western Skies and Competitive Home Prices
description: “Is Tucson in Arizona?” John Lennon asked Paul McCartney as they worked out a hometown for Jojo in “The Beatles: Get Back” documentary. McCartney’s answer: “Yeah, it is, yeah — it’s where they make ‘High Chaparral.’”

title: I Didn’t Like Lifting Until I Tried These Simple Tricks
description: I’m not a big weight room guy. In high school, I got called “Bird Legs,” and in college, I picked up the nickname “Stretch.” I tried to bulk up, but every time I tried, say, bench press, it just felt like too much work and not much fun.

title: What to Know About Today’s Meth
description: Fentanyl overdoses have finally begun to decline over the past year, but that good news has obscured a troubling shift in illicit drug use: a nationwide surge in methamphetamine, a powerful, highly addictive stimulant.

title: Where the Precious Things Are: Maurice Sendak’s Art Collection to Be Auctioned
description: A pre-eminent writer and illustrator of children’s books, Maurice Sendak, who died in 2012 at 83, was also a passionate art collector. The two pursuits were intertwined. “I’m not a collector who collects just for collecting,” he said in 1984. “Things have to refer back or give me some turn-on in my work.”

title: Kids, Inc.
description: The scenes leave a pit in your stomach. In Netflix’s “Bad Influence: The Dark Side of Kidfluencing,” two early teenagers are pressured to kiss by adults — a parent and a videographer — on camera. Hulu’s “The Devil in the Family: The Ruby Franke Story” shows the dramatic footage of Franke’s 12-year-old son showing up at a neighbor’s door with duct tape markings around his ankle, asking them to call police.

title: What’s So Funny About These Albums?
description: Comedians have always wanted to be pop and rock stars — or at least, enough of them have gotten comfortable with a guitar and a drum track to make it seem so. It’s a long and eclectic tradition, including Steve Martin, Weird Al, Bo Burnham, Rachel Bloom, Donald Glover, Randy Rainbow and John Early.

title: A Scrappy Pop-Up Restaurant Shuttles From Coast to Coast
description: Sal’s Place is easy to miss. Almost obscured by bougainvillea, it sits on a corner of North Robertson Boulevard in West Hollywood, Calif., a jumble of a building anchored by a tent draped over a frame of wood and windows. There is no valet parking — even here in Los Angeles — and no sign. To get to a bathroom, diners walk out the front door and turn left on the sidewalk.

title: In Toronto, Waterfront Development Is the End of an Era
description: Francesca Bouaoun woke up on Oct. 3, and looked out the window of her 28th-floor condo, which towers over Toronto’s waterfront with views of Lake Ontario.

title: ‘Now You’re Dead’: Freed Hostage Recounts Captivity in Gaza
description: Hamas gunmen picked the female hostage out from a cluster of captives in an apartment in Gaza. They threatened her with a pistol and led her away into a separate room. Then they commanded Keith Siegel to follow.

title: Joan Chen: Exacting Artist, Cool Mom
description: When Joan Chen was in her early 20s she met with the director Ang Lee about starring in his 1993 film “The Wedding Banquet,” a New York-set rom-com about a Taiwanese American in a relationship with another man who marries a woman in need of a green card. Chen was a star in China but had recently moved to Los Angeles, and was intrigued.

title: A Chicken à la King That’s Actually Fit for a King
description: After leaving the Navy in 1946, a 25-year-old Craig Claiborne moved into a small Chicago apartment to begin his civilian life working in advertising and public relations. During that time, as Claiborne writes in his memoir, “A Feast Made for Laughter,” he cooked meals for himself from an edition of “The Joy of Cooking” his sister gave him for Christmas, along with a chafing dish he lugged home through the snow.

title: Mexico’s Achilles’ Heel as It Faces Trump? Reliance on One U.S. Fuel
description: Hundreds of thousands of lost jobs. Mass poverty. Factories, farms and whole industries left idle and suffering.

title: A Wellness Company With False Claims, Global Aims and a Toronto Island
description: A little-known European company with big ambitions has drawn public outrage in Canada’s largest city.

title: The World’s Most Anticipated Museum Is Finally Open. (Well, Mostly.)
description: I was drawn to the outskirts of Cairo by the colossal complex in the desert — a towering site that arose over decades, built at unimaginable expense, with precisely cut stones sourced from local quarries; a set of buildings whose construction, plagued by extraordinary challenges, spanned the reigns of several rulers; a collective cultural testament, the largest of its kind, teeming with royal history.

title: Faces From a Meth Surge
description: John once fielded customer complaints for a telecommunications company. Now he usually hangs out with friends in the courtyard of a center offering services to help people who use drugs, hitting his pipe, or as he calls it, “getting methicated.”

title: Italy’s Meloni Heads to D.C. Will Her Relationship With Trump Pay Off for Europe?
description: Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni of Italy will become the latest in a line of European leaders to flock to Washington with the goal of currying favor and improving relations with President Trump.

title: ‘The Voyeurs,’ ‘Cyrano’ and More Streaming Gems
description: Edmond Rostand’s late-19th-century play “Cyrano de Bergerac” has proved to be quite a durable text, which shouldn’t come as much of a surprise; few things translate as well, no matter the period or genre, than the feeling that the person you love could never feel the same. This adaptation by the director Joe Wright (“Pride & Prejudice”), first presented onstage by the New Group in 2019, changes the source of the title character’s low self-image: Instead of an oversize nose, he is of undersize height. Peter Dinklage is marvelous in the starring role, finding the cockiness and bluster that Cyrano uses to compensate, while showing the beating heart just under that hard surface. He also provides a pleasant baritone for the songs by members of the National, which are the film’s other key deviation from Rostand’s original. They’re a masterstroke, beautifully conveying the longing and regret of this tragic tale.

title: In Mating Season, a Wild Turkey’s Thoughts Turn to Manhattan
description: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Today we’ll find out about Astoria, the wild turkey who came to Manhattan with a goal in mind. We’ll also get details on the first day of Harvey Weinstein’s new trial in Manhattan.

title: Magical Thinking About a Miracle Mineral
description: I remember when railing against the supposed evils of fluoride in drinking water was the work of a few voices clustered on the fringes of political discourse. The map shifted after Robert F. Kennedy Jr. took office as the secretary of health and human services. Last week he announced that as part of his plan to “make America healthy again,” he would call for an end to fluoridation. Utah has already banned it. Florida is now proposing to do so, and other states seem poised to follow.

title: I’m a Columbia Professor. Here’s the Really Disheartening Part of This Mess.
description: Many of us at Columbia University had lost hope in our struggle with the Trump administration. At the beginning of February, the federal Department of Education announced the school was under investigation. A month later, the Trump administration started canceling the grants and contracts that fund our research labs and medical trials, without producing evidence of wrongdoing. To fend off the White House, Columbia then announced a series of changes, many of which had been long in the works.

title: Not Just ‘Rare Earths’: U.S. Gets Many Critical Minerals From China
description: Three years ago, after the pandemic had laid bare the world’s vulnerability to supply-chain disruptions, the U.S. government designated a large swath of the periodic table of elements — 50 minerals in all — as “critical.”

title: America, This Is an Old and Brutal Tyranny
description: The Trump administration believes it can send anyone it wants, without due process or future legal recourse, to rot in a foreign prison.

title: An Audacious Novelist, Ahead of Her Time, Is Now Getting Her Due
description: In 1981, Nettie Jones was shopping her debut novel, “Fish Tales,” a shocking story about a married woman’s booze- and drug-fueled sexual escapades.

title: Why the White House Started Making Deportation Cartoons
description: Our story opens on March 25 — mere weeks ago, yet somehow already fading into the fog of our eternal present — with OpenAI releasing a new version of ChatGPT. Compared with previous versions, this one was surprisingly good at generating novel digital images: Users could tell it what they wanted to see, and voilà, an image would appear. And what lots of people wanted to see, it transpired, was real photographs transformed to look like stills from the animated films of the Japanese company Studio Ghibli.

title: This Is What Trumponomics Is Really About
description: The tariff onslaught against rivals (except China) and allies has reached somewhat of a pause. But President Trump and his administration have worked at a furious pace in several areas related to political economy, taking a proverbial ax to the government and pushing the bounds of the rule of law.

title: How the White House Press Briefing Is Changing
description: The Trump administration is considering taking control of the seating in the White House press briefing room from the independent White House Correspondents’ Association. Ashley Wu, a graphics reporter for The New York Times, explains why this matters and notes how questions at the briefings have already started to change.

title: Michael B. Jordan, Ryan Coogler and a Dozen Years of Collaborations
